We “rank” the interactions by their strength by looking at how strongly they couple to matter. In other words, the “strength” is measured by the size of the relevant (dimensionless) coupling constant or, more generally, by the probability amplitude calculated from the interaction’s terms in the Lagrangian. Let’s go step by step.

─────────────────────────────  
Step (a): What is “strength”?

1. Coupling constant:
 • In quantum field theory, each force comes with an associated coupling constant which appears in its Lagrangian. For example, for electromagnetism the coupling is the electric charge e (or equivalently the fine–structure constant α ≡ e²/4πħc ≅ 1/137), while for the strong interaction the analogous number is the strong coupling constant (αs), which at typical hadronic energy scales (around 1 GeV) is on the order of unity.
 • For the weak interaction, one often uses the Fermi coupling constant GF ≈ 1.166×10⁻⁵ GeV⁻². (This is not dimensionless but indicates the intrinsic “weakness” of the force when compared on the same energy scale.)  
 • Gravity is extremely feeble at the particle scale; when appropriately “made dimensionless” the gravitational coupling between, say, two protons is typically O(10⁻³⁸) compared to the electromagnetic repulsion.

2. Observable consequences:
 • The larger the coupling, the higher the probability (or cross-section) for processes mediated by that force. For example, strong interaction cross-sections are large compared to those of a single photon exchange.
 • In scattering experiments or decays, one “sees” the relative strengths by comparing reaction rates. (Strong reactions happen very rapidly and produce abundant particles, electromagnetic reactions are slower, and weak decays are “slow” compared to the lifetime scales set by the strong and electromagnetic interactions.)

Thus “strength” is a quantitative measure of the typical interaction amplitude or cross-section as determined by the magnitude of the coupling constant (and related factors such as energy scale and the number of exchanged quanta) in the underlying quantum field theory.

─────────────────────────────  
Step (b): Conservation Laws

It turns out that each of the three non–gravitational forces “selects” the quantum numbers that it automatically conserves. Experimental facts – such as the types of decays observed – then tell us which symmetries each interaction respects.

1. Strong Interaction:
 • Conserved quantum numbers in strong processes include:
  – Baryon number and electric charge.
  – “Flavour” quantum numbers such as strangeness, charm, etc. (Since the gluon, the mediator of the strong force, carries no flavor, it does not change quark flavor.)
  – Color charge is exactly conserved as it is the “charge” of QCD.
  – Parity (P) is conserved in strong interactions.
 • Experimental justification:
  – For instance, strange particles (those with nonzero strangeness) are always produced in pairs in strong interactions. A single hadron carrying strangeness does not appear unless there is a compensating partner. This “selection rule” was historically one of the keys to understanding that strangeness is conserved by the strong force.

2. Electromagnetic Interaction:
 • Conserved quantities in electromagnetic processes include:
  – Electric charge (by gauge invariance under U(1) transformations).
  – Baryon and lepton numbers.
  – Angular momentum and (in most cases) parity are also conserved.
  – In addition, electromagnetic transitions do not change particle flavor.
 • Experimental justification:
  – Photon–induced transitions obey strict conservation of electric charge and parity. Processes such as atomic radiative transitions follow selection rules dictated by electromagnetic gauge invariance.
  – No electromagnetic process has been observed which violates these symmetries.

3. Weak Interaction:
 • The weak force is unusual when compared with the strong and electromagnetic interactions:
  – It conserves electric charge, baryon number, and total lepton number.
  – It violates parity (P) maximally – an experimental fact famously demonstrated by the Wu experiment in the 1950s.
  – It also violates charge conjugation (C) symmetry and, in some processes, even the combined CP symmetry (CP violation observed in decays of K and B mesons).
  – It does not conserve flavor quantum numbers such as strangeness, meaning that weak interactions can change one type of quark into another.
 • Experimental justification:
  – The nonconservation of strangeness in processes like the decay of the K meson clearly shows that flavor is not respected by the weak force.
  – Moreover, the Wu experiment showed that electrons were preferentially emitted in one direction in the beta decay of polarized cobalt nuclei, a clear sign of parity violation.

─────────────────────────────  
Final Answer

(a) “Strength” refers to the magnitude of the coupling constant (or effective coupling) appearing in the interaction Lagrangian, which quantitatively determines the probability amplitude (and hence cross–section, decay rate, etc.) for processes mediated by that force. Strong interactions are “strong” because their coupling (αs) is O(1) at hadronic scales, electromagnetic interactions are weaker (α ≈ 1/137), and weak interactions are even “weaker” (characterized by GF ≈ 10⁻⁵ GeV⁻²), with gravity being negligibly small in particle physics experiments.

(b) The conservation laws followed by the different interactions are as follows:
 • Strong: Conserves baryon number, electric charge, color, and flavor quantum numbers (such as strangeness, charm, etc.) as well as parity. This is evidenced, for instance, by the fact that strange hadrons are produced in pairs in strong processes.
 • Electromagnetic: Conserves electric charge, baryon and lepton number, angular momentum, and parity. Electromagnetic transitions obey strict charge and parity conservation, in accord with the observed selection rules.
 • Weak: Conserves electric charge and overall baryon and lepton number but does not conserve flavor (allowing, for example, strangeness-changing decays) and violates parity and C symmetry (and even CP in certain decays). Experimental observations such as the beta decay asymmetry in the Wu experiment and the nonconservation of strangeness in kaon decays confirm these characteristics.

─────────────────────────────  
Final Answer in Latex

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad &\text{“Strength” is quantified by the size of the coupling constant (or effective coupling) in the interaction Lagrangian,}\\
&\text{which determines the probability (via cross–sections, decay rates, etc.) for the force to act.}\\
&\text{For example, the strong force has } \alpha_s \sim \mathcal{O}(1),\ \text{electromagnetism has } \alpha\approx\frac{1}{137},\text{ and the weak force is}\\
&\text{characterized by } G_F\approx1.166\times10^{-5}\, \text{GeV}^{-2}\text{. Gravity is even much weaker, by roughly 38 orders of magnitude relative}\\
&\text{to electromagnetism at particle scales.} \\
\\
\text{(b)}\quad &\text{In strong interactions: baryon number, electric charge, color, and quark flavor (e.g. strangeness, charm) are conserved,}\\
&\text{as well as parity. (E.g., strange particles are always produced in pairs.)} \\
&\text{In electromagnetic interactions: electric charge, baryon and lepton numbers, angular momentum, and parity are conserved.}\\
&\text{In weak interactions: while electric charge, baryon number, and lepton number are conserved, flavor quantum numbers are not;}\\
&\text{the weak interaction violates parity (and C, and even CP in some cases) as evidenced by beta‐decay and kaon decays.}
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We begin with the process

  π⁻ + d → n + n.

Step 1. Identifying the intrinsic properties

• The π⁻ has spin 0 and intrinsic parity (η_π) of –1.
• The deuteron has spin 1 and intrinsic parity +1.
• The π⁻ is captured from a p orbital, meaning its orbital angular momentum with respect to the deuteron is L_i = 1. The extra orbital factor contributes a parity of (–1)^(L_i) = (–1)¹ = –1.

Step 2. Constructing the initial state

The overall parity of the initial state is given by the product of the intrinsic parities and the orbital parity. Thus,
  P_initial = π⁻ intrinsic parity × deuteron parity × (–1)^(L_i)
       = (–1) × (+1) × (–1)
       = +1.

Also, the initial angular momentum is found by coupling the deuteron’s spin (S_d = 1) with the pion’s orbital angular momentum L_i = 1. The possible total angular momenta are J = 0, 1, or 2. For our discussion, note that one of these channels (J=0) is available; the final state will have total angular momentum zero, as we soon see.

Step 3. Analyzing the final state

The two neutrons produced have the following features:
• Each neutron has intrinsic parity +1.
• The relative orbital angular momentum L_f between the two neutrons contributes a parity factor (–1)^(L_f).

Thus the overall parity of the final state is
  P_final = (+1 × +1) × (–1)^(L_f) = (–1)^(L_f).

Parity conservation requires that P_final = P_initial. We already have P_initial = +1; therefore,
  (–1)^(L_f) = +1,
which implies that L_f must be even (L_f = 0, 2, …). The lowest possibility is L_f = 0.

Step 4. Angular momentum and symmetry restrictions

Let us now consider the spin state of the two neutrons. When L_f = 0, the spatial part of the two-neutron wave function is symmetric. However, neutrons are fermions, and the overall wavefunction must be antisymmetric under the exchange of the two neutrons.

The overall wavefunction is the product of the spatial, spin, and isospin parts. For two neutrons:
• The spatial wavefunction is symmetric (for L_f = 0 or any even L).
• The isospin state for two identical neutrons is necessarily symmetric (they both have the same isospin projection, so they can only form the T = 1 triplet state).
• Therefore, to achieve an overall antisymmetric state, the spin part must be antisymmetric. For two spin-½ particles, the antisymmetric spin state is the singlet state (S = 0).

Step 5. Final Matching of Quantum Numbers

In the final state, with L_f = 0 and S = 0, the total angular momentum is
  J_final = L_f + S = 0 + 0 = 0,
which matches one of the initial J possibilities. Moreover, parity is conserved:
  P_final = (–1)^(0) = +1,
agreeing with P_initial.

Thus, the only way to satisfy angular momentum conservation, parity conservation, and the overall antisymmetry of the wavefunction (given that the isospin state is symmetric) is that the two neutrons emerge in the spin-singlet (S = 0) state.

Final Answer:

\[
\boxed{\text{The two neutrons must be in the } ^1S_0 \text{ state (spin singlet) to satisfy parity, angular momentum, and the antisymmetry of the total wavefunction.}}
\]

solution:
We wish to produce a Z⁰ (mass M_Z = 92 GeV) in the reaction

  e⁺ + e⁻ → Z⁰.

Two experimental scenarios are considered.

───────────────────────────────  
Step (a): Colliding Beams

In a colliding‐beam machine the electron and positron beams are brought into head–on collision. In the center–of–mass (CM) frame the total energy is

  √s = Eₑ⁺ + Eₑ⁻.

For a symmetric machine we can take

  Eₑ⁺ = Eₑ⁻ = E_beam.

To produce an on–shell Z⁰ we require

  √s = M_Z.

Thus,
  2 E_beam = M_Z ⟹ E_beam = M_Z/2.

Numerically,
  E_beam = 92 GeV/2 = 46 GeV.

───────────────────────────────  
Step (b): Fixed–Target (e⁺ beam on e⁻ at rest)

Now the target electron is at rest in the laboratory. Let the positron beam have energy E (we denote it by E_beam now) and momentum p. Its four–momentum is (E, p), with E² = p² + m_e² (we always use units in which c = 1). The target electron’s four–momentum is (m_e, 0). The square of the total four–momentum is

  s = (p_{e⁺} + p_{e⁻})²
    = m_e² + m_e² + 2 m_e E      [since the spatial momentum of the target is zero]
    = 2 m_e (E + m_e).

To produce the Z⁰ we need √s = M_Z. That is,
  M_Z² = 2 m_e (E + m_e).

Solving for E:
  E = (M_Z²/(2 m_e)) – m_e.

Since M_Z ≫ m_e (m_e ≃ 0.000511 GeV) the m_e term is utterly negligible. Inserting the numbers we have

  E ≃ (92² GeV²)/(2 × 0.000511 GeV)
    = (8464 GeV²)/(0.001022 GeV)
    ≃ 8.28 × 10⁶ GeV.

It is often useful to convert into TeV:
  8.28 × 10⁶ GeV = 8.28 × 10³ TeV,
i.e. about 8280 TeV. (This enormous energy requirement is one of the reasons why fixed–target collisions are not used for heavy particles such as the Z⁰.)

───────────────────────────────  
Step (c): Laboratory Energy and Velocity of the Produced Z⁰

In the fixed–target reaction the initial total four–momentum is
  P_initial = p_{e⁺} + p_{e⁻} = (E + m_e, p).

Since the Z⁰ is produced as a single resonance,
  P_Z = P_initial.

Thus, the Z⁰ energy in the lab is
  E_Z = E + m_e ≃ E   (since E ≫ m_e)
and its momentum is
  p_Z = p.

Because the beam is ultrarelativistic we have p ≃ E (to high accuracy). The Lorentz factor of the Z⁰ is then

  γ_Z = E_Z/M_Z ≃ E/M_Z ≃ (8.28×10⁶ GeV)/(92 GeV) ≃ 9×10⁴.

Its speed is given by
  β_Z = p_Z/E_Z ≃ 1 – (1/(2γ_Z²)).
Thus numerically β_Z is extremely close to 1 (i.e. very near the speed of light).

───────────────────────────────  
Step (d): Maximum Laboratory Energy of the Muons

The Z⁰ decays, for example, via
  Z⁰ → μ⁺ + μ⁻.
In the rest frame of the Z⁰ the two muons are produced back–to–back with equal energy. (Neglecting the small mass of the muon, m_μ ≃ 0.105 GeV, relative to M_Z, the energies are)
  E* (μ⁺) = E* (μ⁻) = M_Z/2 = 46 GeV.

Now, a Lorentz boost along the direction of the Z⁰ motion will increase the energy of one of the muons (the one emitted in the same direction as the Z⁰’s motion) to its maximum value. The standard formula is

  E_lab = γ_Z (E* + β_Z p* cos θ*).

For a massless (or ultrarelativistic) muon in the Z⁰ rest frame, p* ≃ E*. The maximum occurs for cos θ* = 1, giving

  E_max = γ_Z (E* + β_Z E*) = γ_Z E*(1 + β_Z).

Since β_Z is almost 1 the factor (1 + β_Z) ≃ 2. Thus one obtains

  E_max ≃ 2 γ_Z E* = 2 (E_Z/M_Z) (M_Z/2) = E_Z.

That is, the maximum laboratory energy of the muon is essentially the same as the energy of the Z⁰ in the lab, i.e.,
  E_max ≃ E + m_e ≃ 8.28 × 10⁶ GeV.

───────────────────────────────  
Final Answers

(a) In a colliding beam facility each beam must have energy 
  Eₑ = M_Z/2 = 46 GeV.

(b) In a fixed–target facility a beam of positrons striking electrons at rest must have energy 
  E ≃ M_Z²/(2 m_e) ≃ 8.28 × 10⁶ GeV  (≈8.28×10³ TeV).

(c) The produced Z⁰ will have laboratory energy 
  E_Z = E + m_e ≃ 8.28 × 10⁶ GeV,
with Lorentz factor γ_Z ≃ 9×10⁴ and speed β_Z extremely close to 1.

(d) The maximum laboratory energy of a muon from Z⁰ → μ⁺ + μ⁻ is approximately
  E_max ≃ E_Z ≃ 8.28 × 10⁶ GeV.

───────────────────────────────  
Final Answer

\[
\boxed{
\begin{array}{rcl}
\text{(a)} &:& E_{e^\pm} = M_Z/2 = 46\ \text{GeV},\\[1mm]
\text{(b)} &:& E_{e^+} \simeq \dfrac{M_Z^2}{2\,m_e} \simeq 8.28\times10^6\ \text{GeV},\\[1mm]
\text{(c)} &:& E_Z \simeq E_{e^+}+m_e \simeq 8.28\times10^6\ \text{GeV},\quad \gamma_Z \simeq 9\times10^4,\quad \beta_Z\approx 1,\\[1mm]
\text{(d)} &:& E_{\mu}^{\rm max} \simeq 2\gamma_Z\,(M_Z/2) \simeq E_Z \simeq 8.28\times10^6\ \text{GeV}.
\end{array}
}
\]

We wish to determine the momenta (magnitudes and directions) in the laboratory (lab) frame of the two particles from the decay

  Ξ⁻ → Λ⁰ + π⁻.

We are given:
 • Masses (rest energies) [with c = 1]:
  M_Ξ = 1.3 GeV,
  M_Λ = 1.1 GeV,
  M_π = 0.14 GeV.
 • The Ξ⁻ in the lab has momentum p_Ξ = 2 GeV/c along the +x‐axis.
 • In the Ξ⁻ rest (center–of–mass) frame the Λ⁰ is produced with momentum making an angle 30° with the direction of the original Ξ⁻ (i.e. with the +x–axis). (Since the two–body decay produces a back–to–back pair, the π⁻ is emitted in the opposite direction to the Λ⁰ in the Ξ⁻ rest frame.)

Our procedure is as follows:
 1. Find the magnitude of the momentum in the Ξ⁻ rest frame (the “decay momentum”) using energy–momentum conservation.
 2. Write the 4–momenta of Λ⁰ (and π⁻) in the Ξ⁻ rest frame.
 3. Boost these 4–momenta to the lab frame (knowing the boost is along the x-axis).
 4. Read off the lab momentum components and compute the overall momentum magnitude and the angle relative to the +x–axis.

───────────────────────────── Step 1. Decay momentum in the Ξ⁻ rest frame

For a two–body decay A → 1 + 2 the momentum (common to both daughters in the A rest frame) is given by

  p* = [√((M_A² − (m₁ + m₂)²)(M_A² − (m₁ − m₂)²)]/(2M_A).

Here M_A = M_Ξ = 1.3 GeV, m₁ = M_Λ = 1.1 GeV, and m₂ = M_π = 0.14 GeV.

First, compute:
  m₁ + m₂ = 1.1 + 0.14 = 1.24  → (1.24)² = 1.5376,
  m₁ − m₂ = 1.1 − 0.14 = 0.96  → (0.96)² = 0.9216,
  M_Ξ² = (1.3)² = 1.69.

Now,
  M_Ξ² – (m₁ + m₂)² = 1.69 − 1.5376 = 0.1524,
  M_Ξ² – (m₁ − m₂)² = 1.69 − 0.9216 = 0.7684.

Thus the product is
  0.1524 × 0.7684 ≈ 0.1170,
so that
  p* = √(0.1170) / (2·1.3) = 0.342 GeV / 2.6 ≈ 0.1315 GeV/c.

This means that in the Ξ⁻ rest frame both Λ⁰ and π⁻ have magnitudes p* ≈ 0.132 GeV/c.

───────────────────────────── Step 2. 4–momenta in the Ξ⁻ rest frame

By our choice the boost (and the original Ξ⁻ motion) is in the +x direction. In the Ξ⁻ rest frame we have:
 • Λ⁰:
  its momentum magnitude: p*ₗ = 0.1315 GeV/c,
  its direction: 30° from the +x–axis.
 So, its x– and y–components are:
  p*ₗ,x = 0.1315 cos 30° ≈ 0.1315 × 0.8660 ≈ 0.1138 GeV/c,
  p*ₗ,y = 0.1315 sin 30° ≈ 0.1315 × 0.5 = 0.06575 GeV/c.
 Its energy is
  E*ₗ = √(M_Λ² + p*²) = √(1.1² + 0.1315²) ≈ √(1.21 + 0.0173) ≈ √(1.2273) ≈ 1.107 GeV.

 • π⁻:
  Since momentum is conserved (back‐to–back decay), its momentum in the Ξ⁻ rest frame is equal in magnitude but opposite in direction to that of the Λ⁰. Thus,
  p*π,x = –0.1138 GeV/c, p*π,y = –0.06575 GeV/c,
  and its energy is
  E*π = √(M_π² + p*²) = √(0.14² + 0.1315²) = √(0.0196 + 0.0173) ≈ √(0.0369) ≈ 0.1922 GeV.

───────────────────────────── Step 3. Boost to the Lab Frame

The lab frame is related to the Ξ⁻ rest frame by a boost along the +x–axis. First, we determine the parameters of the boost.

The Ξ⁻ in the lab has momentum p_Ξ = 2 GeV/c and energy
  E_Ξ = √(p_Ξ² + M_Ξ²) = √(4 + 1.69) = √(5.69) ≈ 2.387 GeV.
So the boost speed is
  β = p_Ξ/E_Ξ ≈ 2/2.387 ≈ 0.838,
and the corresponding Lorentz factor is
  γ = 1/√(1 − β²) ≈ 2.387/1.3 ≈ 1.8338.

Since the boost is along x, the Lorentz transformations for a particle with energy E* and momentum components (p*_x, p*_y) are:
  E_lab = γ (E* + β p*_x),
  p_lab,x = γ (p*_x + β E*),
  p_lab,y = p*_y   (unchanged).

Let us apply these to each daughter.

───────────────────────────── For Λ⁰

In the Ξ⁻ rest frame:
 E*ₗ ≈ 1.107 GeV,
 p*ₗ,x ≈ 0.1138 GeV/c,
 p*ₗ,y ≈ 0.06575 GeV/c.

Thus, in the lab frame:
 Eₗ = γ (E*ₗ + β p*ₗ,x)
  ≈ 1.8338 · (1.107 + 0.838 · 0.1138)
  ≈ 1.8338 · (1.107 + 0.0955)
  ≈ 1.8338 · 1.2025 ≈ 2.205 GeV.

And
 pₗ,x = γ (p*ₗ,x + β E*ₗ)
  ≈ 1.8338 · (0.1138 + 0.838 · 1.107)
  ≈ 1.8338 · (0.1138 + 0.928)  [since 0.838×1.107 ≈ 0.928]
  ≈ 1.8338 · 1.0418 ≈ 1.911 GeV/c.
 pₗ,y = 0.06575 GeV/c.

The magnitude of the Λ⁰ lab momentum is
 |pₗ| = √( (1.911)² + (0.06575)² )
  ≈ √(3.652 + 0.00432) ≈ √(3.6563) ≈ 1.911 GeV/c.

Its angle with respect to the x–axis is
 tan θₗ = pₗ,y/pₗ,x ≈ 0.06575/1.911 ≈ 0.0344  → θₗ ≈ 1.97°.
So the Λ⁰ emerges almost along the original Ξ⁻ direction (only about 2° deflection upward).

───────────────────────────── For π⁻

In the Ξ⁻ rest frame:
 E*π ≈ 0.1922 GeV,
 p*π,x = –0.1138 GeV/c,
 p*π,y = –0.06575 GeV/c.

Boosting along x:
 E_π = γ (E*π + β p*π,x)
  ≈ 1.8338 · (0.1922 + 0.838 · (–0.1138))
  ≈ 1.8338 · (0.1922 − 0.0955)
  ≈ 1.8338 · 0.0967 ≈ 0.1775 GeV.
 p_π,x = γ (p*π,x + β E*π)
  ≈ 1.8338 · (–0.1138 + 0.838·0.1922)
  ≈ 1.8338 · (–0.1138 + 0.1612)
  ≈ 1.8338 · 0.0474 ≈ 0.0869 GeV/c.
 p_π,y = –0.06575 GeV/c.

The magnitude of the π⁻ momentum in the lab is
 |p_π| = √( (0.0869)² + (–0.06575)² )
  ≈ √(0.00755 + 0.00432) ≈ √(0.01187) ≈ 0.109 GeV/c.

Its direction is given by
 tan θ_π = |p_π,y|/p_π,x ≈ 0.06575/0.0869 ≈ 0.7563  → θ_π ≈ 37°.
Since p_π,x is positive but p_π,y is negative, the π⁻ goes 37° below the positive x–axis.

───────────────────────────── Step 4. Final Answers

Thus, in the lab frame the decay products are observed with approximately:

 • Λ⁰:
  Momentum ≈ 1.91 GeV/c,
  Angle ≈ 2° above the x–axis.
 • π⁻:
  Momentum ≈ 0.11 GeV/c,
  Angle ≈ 37° below the x–axis.

These numbers are consistent with energy–momentum conservation (for example, the total lab energy of Λ⁰ (≈2.205 GeV) plus π⁻ (≈0.1775 GeV) is ≈2.3825 GeV, very near the Ξ⁻ lab energy 2.387 GeV).

──────────────────────────── Final Answer

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{In the lab: } & \Lambda^0 \text{ has } p\approx1.91\,\text{GeV/c, emerging at } \theta\approx2^\circ \text{ (above +x),} \\
& \pi^- \text{ has } p\approx0.11\,\text{GeV/c, emerging at } \theta\approx37^\circ \text{ (below +x).}
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We begin by recalling that momentum is an ordinary (polar) vector whereas spin is an axial (pseudovector) quantity.

Step 1. Transformations under Parity (P) and Time Reversal (T):

(a) Under the parity operator P, spatial coordinates reverse sign. Therefore:
 • The momentum, being a polar vector, transforms as
  p → –p.
 • The spin, being an axial vector (involving a cross product of two polar vectors), remains unchanged:
  s → s.

Under the time reversal operator T, not only are the coordinates time‐reversed, but velocities (and hence momentum) and angular momenta (including spin) reverse sign. Thus:
 • The momentum transforms as
  p → –p.
 • The spin transforms as
  s → –s.

Thus, our answer for part (a) is:
 • Under P: p → –p, s → s.
 • Under T: p → –p, s → –s.

Step 2. Looking for T Violation in Λ → N + π:

(b) Since the spin and momenta transform differently under T and P, one can construct observables (or correlations) that are odd under time reversal but even under parity. A common choice is to look at a triple correlation of the form

  s_Λ · (p_N × p_π).

Let us check its properties:
 • Under parity: p_N and p_π each change sign, so the cross product (p_N × p_π) is invariant (since (–p_N × –p_π) = p_N × p_π). The Λ spin s_Λ remains unchanged under P, so the triple product is even under P.
 • Under time reversal: Both momenta and spin change sign. Thus p_N and p_π contribute a sign flip each and s_Λ a sign flip,
  s_Λ → –s_Λ, p_N → –p_N, p_π → –p_π,
so the cross product (–p_N × –p_π) remains unchanged (as (–p_N × –p_π) = p_N × p_π), but the overall triple product changes sign,
  s_Λ · (p_N × p_π) → (–s_Λ) · (p_N × p_π) = –[s_Λ · (p_N × p_π)].
Thus, s_Λ · (p_N × p_π) is odd under T.

A nonzero expectation value for this T–odd observable in the decay would be an indication of T violation. However, one must be cautious: even if the underlying interaction is T–invariant, final state interactions (the so–called “strong phases”) can mimic a T–odd effect. Therefore, any experimental claim for time reversal violation must carefully estimate and subtract the effects arising from final state rescattering.

Furthermore, from an experimental point of view, one needs a polarized Λ beam or a way to determine the polarization of Λ (which comes from its production mechanism) so that the initial s_Λ is well‐known. Without such control, measuring the correlation would be ambiguous.

Thus, for part (b), one may look for a nonzero triple correlation s_Λ · (p_N × p_π) in the decay Λ → N + π, but it is crucial to have control over and understand possible final state interactions, as well as having a means of determining the initial polarization of the Λ.

Final Answer:

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad &\hat{P}:~ \mathbf{p} \to -\mathbf{p},\quad \mathbf{s} \to \mathbf{s};\\[1mm]
&\hat{T}:~ \mathbf{p} \to -\mathbf{p},\quad \mathbf{s} \to -\mathbf{s}.\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad &\text{One may search for T-violation by measuring a T-odd observable, e.g., }\\
&\quad \mathbf{s}_\Lambda \cdot (\mathbf{p}_N \times \mathbf{p}_\pi).\\[1mm]
&\text{A nonzero expectation value indicates T violation, provided that effects} \\
&\text{due to final state interactions are carefully estimated and the initial } \\
&\text{$\Lambda$ polarization is well determined.}
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We begin by analyzing the initial conditions. We have two particles, both of rest mass m:

1. The first particle is moving and has a kinetic energy equal to twice its rest energy. Since the rest energy is m c², its kinetic energy is 2m c². Therefore, its total energy is

  E₁ = m c² + 2m c² = 3m c².

2. The second particle is at rest, so its energy is simply

  E₂ = m c².

The momentum of the second particle is zero, so only the first particle contributes to the total momentum.

Step 1. Calculate the momentum of the moving particle.
The energy and momentum of a relativistic particle satisfy the relation

  E² = (pc)² + (mc²)².
Substitute E₁ = 3m c²:

  (3m c²)² = (p₁ c)² + (m c²)²
  9m² c⁴ = (p₁ c)² + m² c⁴.

Solving for p₁:

  (p₁ c)² = 9m² c⁴ − m² c⁴ = 8m² c⁴
  p₁ = √(8m² c⁴) / c = 2√2 m c.

Step 2. Compute the total energy and momentum of the system.
The total energy is:

  E_total = E₁ + E₂ = 3m c² + m c² = 4m c².

The total momentum is just the momentum of the first particle:

  p_total = 2√2 m c.

Step 3. Find the invariant mass (rest mass) of the combined particle.
When the two particles combine, the invariant mass M of the new particle is determined by

  M² c⁴ = E_total² − (p_total c)².
Substitute the values:

  M² c⁴ = (4m c²)² − (2√2 m c · c)²
    = 16m² c⁴ − (2√2 m c²)².

Since (2√2 m c²)² = 8m² c⁴, we have:

  M² c⁴ = 16m² c⁴ − 8m² c⁴ = 8m² c⁴.

Solving for M:

  M² = 8m²  ⟹  M = 2√2 m.

Thus, the rest mass of the new combined particle is 2√2 m.

Final Answer: \[\boxed{2\sqrt{2}\, m}\]

solution:
We will answer each part step by step.

─────────────────────────────  
Step 1. (a) Writing the Reaction Equation

A negative muon (μ⁻) is a charged lepton similar to the electron but about 207 times heavier. Its decay is mediated by the weak interaction. One common decay mode is into an electron (e⁻), an electron‐antineutrino ( \( \bar{\nu}_e\) ), and a muon neutrino ( \( \nu_\mu\) ). Thus one can write the decay reaction as

  μ⁻ → e⁻ + \( \bar{\nu}_e\) + \( \nu_\mu\).

In words, the particles involved are:
 • The μ⁻ (negative muon), a heavy charged lepton.
 • The e⁻ (electron), a light charged lepton.
 • The \( \bar{\nu}_e\) (electron antineutrino), the anti‐particle associated with the electron.
 • The \( \nu_\mu\) (muon neutrino), the neutrino associated with the muon.

─────────────────────────────  
Step 2. (b) Can a Lepton from This Decay Convert a Proton into a Neutron?

One might ask if one of the leptons produced in the muon decay could “convert” a proton at rest into a neutron. The relevant process to consider is similar to electron capture by a proton. In ordinary electron capture within a nucleus the process is

  p + e⁻ → n + \( \nu_e\),

where a proton (p) combines with an electron (e⁻) to form a neutron (n) and an electron neutrino (\( \nu_e\)). For a free proton, one must consider the energy balance. The rest masses are approximately:

 • m(p) ≈ 938.272 MeV,  
 • m(e) ≈ 0.511 MeV,  
 • m(n) ≈ 939.565 MeV.

Thus the total rest energy of the initial state is

  938.272 MeV + 0.511 MeV = 938.783 MeV

and that of the final neutron is about 939.565 MeV. This shows that an extra roughly

  939.565 MeV – 938.783 MeV ≈ 0.782 MeV

is needed. In other words, the electron must bring at least about 0.782 MeV of kinetic energy in order for the reaction to be energetically possible.

When a μ⁻ decays at rest its available energy is the muon rest mass (about 105.66 MeV) which is shared among the three products. The energy distribution of the decay electron (often called the Michel spectrum) extends from nearly zero up to a maximum of roughly 105 MeV. Thus, many of the decay electrons will have more than 0.782 MeV of kinetic energy.

Therefore, if a decay electron (from μ⁻ → e⁻ + \( \bar{\nu}_e\) + \( \nu_\mu\)) were to interact with a proton at rest, it could indeed supply the extra energy required to convert the proton into a neutron via the weak interaction as

  e⁻ + p → n + \( \nu_e\).

In this process the energetic electron is captured by the proton, and a neutrino carries off the extra energy and momentum so that energy-momentum is conserved.

─────────────────────────────  
Final Answer

(a) The decay reaction is

  μ⁻ → e⁻ + \( \bar{\nu}_e\) + \( \nu_\mu\),

with μ⁻ being the negative muon, e⁻ the electron, \( \bar{\nu}_e\) the electron antineutrino, and \( \nu_\mu\) the muon neutrino.

(b) Yes. An electron from the decay (if it has more than about 0.782 MeV of kinetic energy) can interact with a proton at rest via the reaction

  e⁻ + p → n + \( \nu_e\).

Because the decay electrons can have energies up to around 105 MeV, there is more than enough energy to allow the conversion.

─────────────────────────────  
Final Answer in Latex Boxed Format

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
&(a)\quad \mu^- \to e^- + \bar{\nu}_e + \nu_\mu, \quad \text{with μ⁻ (negative muon), e⁻ (electron), } \\
&\quad\quad \bar{\nu}_e\ (\text{electron antineutrino}),\ \nu_\mu\ (\text{muon neutrino}).\\[1mm]
&(b)\quad \text{Yes. An energetic decay electron can convert a proton into a neutron via } \\
&\quad e^- + p \to n + \nu_e,\ \text{since the electron can easily supply the 0.782 MeV needed above the rest-energy threshold.}
\end{aligned}
}
\]

solution:
We now show step‐by‐step how one may arrive at the answers.

Let us consider the reaction

  π⁻ + d → n + n

where the deuteron is in a ³S₁ state (i.e. a spin–triplet with zero orbital angular momentum) and the pion is a pseudoscalar (J^P = 0⁻). (We assume here that any possible small corrections due to the long‐range Coulomb wave function in the atomic state are not important for the angular momentum/isospin selection rules.) Conservation of angular momentum and parity in the strong interaction fixes the quantum numbers of the final two–neutron state.

─────────────────────────────

Step 1. (Orbital Angular Momentum)

The intrinsic parity of the pion is “odd” (–) while that of the deuteron (made from nucleons with intrinsic parity + and with L = 0) is “even” (+). Thus the initial state parity is

  P_initial = P(π) × P(d) = (–)(+) = –.

In the final state the intrinsic parity of two neutrons is (+)(+)= +, so that any overall parity must come from the orbital motion. Since the parity associated with orbital angular momentum L is (–1)^L, parity conservation requires

  (–1)^L = P_final = P_initial = –   ⟹   L odd.

For the reaction to occur near threshold the smallest possible L is favored so we must have L = 1.

Thus, (a) the orbital angular momentum of the neutron pair is L = 1 (a P–wave).

─────────────────────────────

Step 2. (Spin of the Two Neutrons)

The deuteron has total angular momentum J = 1 coming entirely from spin (S = 1) as it is in an S–wave. The π–meson carries no spin. Therefore total J_initial = 1.

Now, the two neutrons are identical fermions. Their full wave function must be antisymmetric under exchange. Their isospin state will be symmetric because two neutrons, having the same third‐component, necessarily combine into an isospin I = 1 state (recall that the deuteron has I = 0, so there is, in fact, an isospin flip in the reaction). Since the spatial (orbital, L = 1) part is antisymmetric (because an L = 1 orbital wave function changes sign under exchange, due to the factor (–1)^L = –1) the spin part must be symmetric so that the overall spin ⊗ space wave function is antisymmetric when multiplied by the symmetric isospin part. (That is, one has “antisymmetric spatial” × “symmetric spin” × “symmetric isospin” giving an overall antisymmetric state.) For two spin–½ particles a symmetric spin state means S = 1 (the “triplet”). 

Thus, (b) the two neutrons are in a spin–triplet state (S = 1).

─────────────────────────────

Step 3. (Probability that Both Neutron Spins are Opposite to the Deuteron’s Spin)

Let us adopt our quantization (z–axis) so that the initial deuteron is 100% polarized with spin “up” (m_d = +1). In the final state the two–neutron system must also have total J = 1. Since we already have L = 1 and S = 1, the two vectors couple to produce J = 1. Writing the Clebsch–Gordan expansion we have

  |J = 1, M = +1⟩ = √(2/3) |L = 1, m_L = +1⟩|S = 1, m_S = 0⟩
         + √(1/3) |L = 1, m_L = 0⟩|S = 1, m_S = +1⟩.

Now, in a two–spin–½ system the triplet states are given by

  |1, +1⟩ = |↑↑⟩,
  |1, 0⟩ = 1/√2 (|↑↓⟩ + |↓↑⟩),
  |1, –1⟩ = |↓↓⟩.

Notice that the possibility for both neutron spins to be “down” (i.e. opposite to the deuteron’s spin) corresponds to the m_S = –1 state: |↓↓⟩. However, in the expansion above there is no contribution from the m_S = –1 part. (In fact, since M = m_L + m_S = +1 and m_S = –1 would require m_L = +2, which is impossible for L = 1.) 

Thus, (c) the probability for finding both neutron spins directed opposite to the deuteron’s spin is zero.

─────────────────────────────

Step 4. (Angular Dependence for a Neutron with Spin Opposite to the Deuteron)

Still assuming the deuteron is polarized with m_d = +1, the final two–neutron state is

  |Ψ_final⟩ = √(2/3) Y₁^(+1)(θ, φ) |S = 1, m_S = 0⟩ + √(1/3) Y₁^(0)(θ, φ) |S = 1, m_S = +1⟩.

Now, when measuring the spin of an individual neutron, even though the two–particle state is entangled, one may ask: what is the angular distribution (i.e. the dependence on the emission angles θ and φ) for the neutron that is observed with its spin “down” (i.e. opposite to the deuteron’s polarization direction)?

Examine the two pieces:
• The second term carries |S = 1, m_S = +1⟩ = |↑↑⟩ so that both neutrons are “up”. It cannot contribute to an event where one neutron is measured “down.”
• The first term has |S = 1, m_S = 0⟩ = 1/√2 (|↑↓⟩ + |↓↑⟩); a given neutron in this configuration has a 50% chance (1/2) of being spin “down.”

Thus, the only contribution for detecting a “down” neutron comes from the m_S = 0 piece, with amplitude

  A(θ, φ) = √(2/3) Y₁^(+1)(θ, φ) × (1/√2) = √(1/3) Y₁^(+1)(θ, φ).

Recalling the given spherical harmonic

  Y₁^(+1)(θ, φ) = – sin θ e^(+iφ),

we deduce that the probability (per unit solid angle) is proportional to

  |A(θ, φ)|² ∝ (1/3) |sin θ|² = (1/3) sin²θ.

Thus, (d) if the deuteron’s spin is 100% polarized in the k–direction, the angular distribution (up to an overall normalization) for detecting a neutron whose spin is opposite (down) is

  dW/dΩ ∝ sin²θ.

─────────────────────────────

Final Answers

(a) L = 1.

(b) S = 1 (the two neutrons form a spin–triplet).

(c) The probability for both neutron spins to be opposite to the deuteron’s spin is zero.

(d) For a 100% polarized deuteron (spin up), the angular distribution (per unit solid angle) for a neutron detected with spin down is proportional to sin²θ; i.e.,
  dW/dΩ ∝ sin²θ.

Thus, our final boxed answers are:

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}&\quad L=1,\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}&\quad S=1,\\[1mm]
\text{(c)}&\quad P(\text{both spins down})=0,\\[1mm]
\text{(d)}&\quad \frac{dW}{d\Omega}\propto\sin^2\theta.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We wish to relate the integrated, spin‐averaged cross sections for the two reactions

  (I) γ + p → π⁺ + n  and  (II) π⁺ + n → γ + p

at the same total center‐of‐mass energy W. In what follows we shall denote by σI(W) the cross section for (I) and by σII(W) the cross section for (II).

Many textbooks show that for a generic two‐body reaction the (averaged and summed) cross section may be written as

  σ = (1⁄(64π² s)) (|p_f|/|p_i|) |M|²,
     (1)

where s = W², |p_i| and |p_f| are respectively the magnitudes of the initial and final center‐of‐mass momenta, and |M|² is the invariant squared matrix element (with the averaging of initial spins included). (For notational simplicity we are suppressing additional constant factors; they cancel when one relates the direct and the inverse process.) Time-reversal invariance tells us that the invariant amplitude (and hence |M|²) is the same for both reactions. However, the phase space (and also the flux factors) are different.

Below we describe in some detail how the relation comes about.

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. Write the Two Cross Sections

For reaction (I): γ + p → π⁺ + n, using (1) we have

  σI = (1/(64π² s)) (qπ/kγ) |M_I|²,
    (2)

and for the inverse reaction (II): π⁺ + n → γ + p we have

  σII = (1/(64π² s)) (kγ/qπ) |M_{II}|²,
    (3)

where

  kγ ≡ center‐of‐mass momentum of the photon (in reaction I, it is also the magnitude of the initial photon three‐momentum)
  qπ ≡ center‐of‐mass momentum of the pion in reaction (I) (which is also that of the initial π⁺ in reaction (II)).

Time reversal invariance relates the invariant amplitudes for the two processes. However, one must also recall that the numerical factors that enter the “averaged” |M|² depend on the number of polarization (or spin) states in the initial channel. (By definition, σI is obtained by averaging over the two photon polarizations and the two proton spin states, while σII is averaged over the one pion state and the two neutron spin states.)

Thus, if we denote by Σ|M|² the “raw” (spin‐summed) squared amplitude, then one may write
  |M_I|² = (1/4) Σ|M|²   (for γ + p, 2×2 states)
  |M_{II}|² = (1/2) Σ|M|²   (for π⁺ + n, 1×2 states)

When these are inserted into (2) and (3) and then the ratio σII/σI is taken, one finds

  σII/σI = [(kγ/qπ) (1/2)]⁄[(qπ/kγ) (1/4)] = 2 (kγ/qπ)².
    (4)

──────────────────────────────
Step 2. Write the Detailed Balance Relation

Thus, detailed balance gives

  σII(W) = 2 (kγ(W)/qπ(W))² σI(W),  (5)

with

  kγ(W) = (W² – m²)/(2W),  (6)
  qπ(W) = (1/(2W)) √[(W² – (m + μ)²)(W² – (m – μ)²)],  (7)

where m is the nucleon mass and μ the pion mass (we neglect the small neutron–proton mass difference).

──────────────────────────────
Step 3. Reaction II Threshold and Near‐Threshold Behavior

For reaction (II): π⁺ + n → γ + p, the initial particles have masses μ and m respectively. Thus the minimal invariant mass (the “threshold” in the center‐of‐mass frame) is

  W_thresh = m + μ.  (8)

Next, notice that in reaction (I) the center‐of‐mass phase–space factor (and hence σI) contains a factor qπ (as seen in Eq. (2)). In most realistic cases the amplitude |M|² is a smooth function of energy, so near threshold we expect

  σI(W) ∝ qπ   (as W → m + μ).
    (9)

Now, from (5),

  σII(W) = 2 (kγ/qπ)² σI(W).  (5, repeated)

Since the photon is massless, kγ (given in (6)) is nonzero at threshold even though qπ goes to zero (qπ ∝ √(W – (m + μ))). Therefore, very near threshold we have

  σII(W) ∝ (1/qπ) ∝ 1/√(W – (m + μ)).  (10)

That is, just above threshold the cross section for reaction (II) rises very sharply, diverging as 1/√(W – (m + μ)) (this divergence is a typical kinematical consequence when the reaction rate is expressed in terms of a cross section with an incident particle whose flux vanishes at threshold).

──────────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) Detailed balance predicts that

  σII(W) = 2 (kγ(W)/qπ(W))² σI(W),

with
  kγ(W) = (W² – m²)/(2W) and qπ(W) = [((W² – (m + μ)²)(W² – (m – μ)²)]^(1/2)/(2W).

(b) For reaction (II) the threshold energy in the center‐of‐mass frame is

  W_thresh = m + μ,

and since σI(W) ∝ qπ ∝ √(W – (m + μ)) just above threshold, it follows that

  σII(W) ∝ 1/√(W – (m + μ)) as W → (m + μ)+.

Thus, while σI vanishes in a “usual” square‐root fashion as threshold is approached, σII (defined via the vanishing flux of the low–energy pion) diverges as 1/√(W – (m + μ)).

We begin by comparing the center‐of‐mass (CM) energies in the two situations.

Step 1. Colliding Beams (Head‐on collision):

Two protons (each of total energy E = 30 GeV) are moving in opposite directions. Their four–momenta are
  P₁ = (E, p⃗)  and  P₂ = (E, –p⃗).
The square of the total four–momentum is
  s = (P₁ + P₂)² = (E + E)² – (p⃗ + (–p⃗))² = (2E)² = 4E².
Thus,
  s = 4(30 GeV)² = 3600 GeV².
The corresponding CM energy is √s = 60 GeV.

Step 2. Fixed–Target Collision:

Now one proton is at rest and the other (beam proton) has total energy E (to be determined). The stationary proton has four–momentum
  P₂ = (m_p, 0),
where m_p is the proton rest mass (≈0.938 GeV). The incoming proton has four–momentum
  P₁ = (E, p⃗)  with  |p⃗|² = E² – m_p².
Then
  s = (P₁ + P₂)² = (E + m_p)² – p⃗²
    = (E + m_p)² – (E² – m_p²)
    = E² + 2Em_p + m_p² – E² + m_p²
    = 2m_p(E + m_p).
For the fixed–target collision to yield the same center–of–mass energy as the colliding–beam case, we set
  2m_p (E + m_p) = 3600 GeV².
Solving for E:
  E + m_p = 3600/(2m_p) = 1800/m_p,
  E = (1800/m_p) – m_p.

Step 3. Numerical Calculation:

Using m_p ≈ 0.938 GeV,
  E = (1800 / 0.938) – 0.938 ≈ 1918 – 0.938 ≈ 1917 GeV.
Thus, the beam proton in a fixed–target experiment must have an energy of about 1917 GeV (approximately 1.9 TeV) to achieve the same 60 GeV center–of–mass energy as two 30 GeV protons colliding head–on.

Final Answer:

\[\boxed{E \approx 1.9 \times 10^3\, \text{GeV}}\]

We start by noting that the strong interaction conserves strangeness. This means that if you start with a state that has zero strangeness then a strong interaction cannot produce a state in which only one strange quark (or one strange particle) is present (because that state has nonzero strangeness). To produce strange particles strongly, you must create them in pairs (a strange and an anti‐strange), so that overall strangeness is conserved.

Now, consider part (a): A state containing one strange particle (i.e., having nonzero net strangeness) can decay into a state of zero strangeness. This decay, however, must occur via the weak interaction, which does not conserve strangeness. Thus, (a) is a true statement.

Next, consider (b): A state containing one strange particle cannot be created by a strong interaction from a state of zero strangeness, because the strong interaction conserves strangeness. The production of a strange particle by the strong interaction requires the simultaneous creation of another particle with an opposite strangeness (often an anti‐strange partner). Thus, (b) is false.

Finally, part (c) states that such a state "cannot exist." This is not true because many particles (such as the kaons, hyperons, etc.) contain one strange quark (or one strange antiquark) and are perfectly real and observable particles, albeit decaying via the weak interaction.

Thus, the only correct statement is (a).

\[\boxed{\text{(a) can decay into a state of zero strangeness.}}\]

solution:
We wish to determine the incident energy of the K⁻ (denoted by Eₖ) for which the Λ⁰ is produced at rest in the laboratory. The reaction is

  K⁻ + p → π⁰ + Λ⁰,

with the proton initially at rest. In the lab frame, let the 4‐momenta be

  K⁻: (Eₖ, p⃗)
  p: (m_p, 0)
  π⁰: (E_π, p⃗_π)
  Λ⁰: (m_Λ, 0)        [since Λ⁰ is at rest].

Because momentum is conserved, and the Λ⁰ is at rest, the π⁰ must carry all the momentum. Thus, momentum conservation tells us

  p⃗_π = p⃗     (1)

Also, energy conservation gives

  Eₖ + m_p = E_π + m_Λ.   (2)

The energies of the K⁻ and π⁰ are given (in natural units, c = 1) by

  Eₖ = √(m_{K⁻}² + p²),
  E_π = √(m_{π⁰}² + p²).

Our goal is to find Eₖ for which these relations hold.

Step 1. Write the energy conservation equation explicitly:
  √(m_{K⁻}² + p²) + m_p = √(m_{π⁰}² + p²) + m_Λ.

Step 2. Isolate the square root term for the K⁻ energy:
  √(m_{K⁻}² + p²) = √(m_{π⁰}² + p²) + (m_Λ - m_p).

Step 3. Now, express the K⁻ energy Eₖ in terms of p using the above equation. However, noticing that the momentum p appears in both square root terms, an easier strategy is to eliminate the momentum variable by reexpressing everything in terms of Eₖ. Since the π⁰ momentum p is the same as that of the K⁻, we have
  p² = Eₖ² - m_{K⁻}².

Thus, the energy of the π⁰ becomes
  E_π = √(m_{π⁰}² + Eₖ² - m_{K⁻}²).

Then, energy conservation (2) becomes

  Eₖ + m_p = √(m_{π⁰}² + Eₖ² - m_{K⁻}²) + m_Λ.

Step 4. Rearrange to isolate the square root term:

  Eₖ - (m_Λ - m_p) = √(Eₖ² - m_{K⁻}² + m_{π⁰}²).

Step 5. Square both sides to remove the square root:

  [Eₖ - (m_Λ - m_p)]² = Eₖ² - m_{K⁻}² + m_{π⁰}².

Expanding the left-hand side yields

  Eₖ² - 2Eₖ(m_Λ - m_p) + (m_Λ - m_p)² = Eₖ² - m_{K⁻}² + m_{π⁰}².

Notice that Eₖ² cancels out on both sides. We are then left with

  - 2Eₖ(m_Λ - m_p) + (m_Λ - m_p)² = - m_{K⁻}² + m_{π⁰}².

Step 6. Solve for Eₖ:

First, bring the term with Eₖ to one side:
  2Eₖ(m_Λ - m_p) = m_{K⁻}² - m_{π⁰}² + (m_Λ - m_p)².

Thus,

  Eₖ = [m_{K⁻}² - m_{π⁰}² + (m_Λ - m_p)²] / [2 (m_Λ - m_p)].

This is the special value of the incident K⁻ energy such that the Λ⁰ is produced at rest in the laboratory.

Final Answer in boxed LaTeX:
  \[\boxed{ E_{K^-} = \frac{m_{K^-}^2 - m_{\pi^0}^2 + \left(m_{\Lambda^0} - m_p\right)^2}{2\left(m_{\Lambda^0} - m_p\right)} }\]
final_answers: E_{K^-} = \frac{m_{K^-}^2 - m_{\pi^0}^2 + \left(m_{\Lambda^0} - m_p\right)^2}{2\left(m_{\Lambda^0} - m_p\right)}

We start with two important lengths:

1. The electron Compton wavelength is usually defined as
  λ_C = h/(m_e c)
which has the numerical value
  λ_C ≈ 2.426 × 10^(–12) m.

2. The Bohr radius is defined as
  a₀ = 4πε₀ ħ²/(m_e e²)
and its value is
  a₀ ≈ 5.29 × 10^(–11) m.

It is often illuminating to express a₀ in terms of the reduced Compton wavelength λ̄_C which is given by
  λ̄_C = ħ/(m_e c).

Notice that the fine–structure constant α is defined as
  α = e²/(4πε₀ ħ c).

In terms of these, one may rewrite the Bohr radius as follows:
  a₀ = [ħ/(m_e c)] × [ħ c/(e²/(4πε₀)]
    = λ̄_C / α.

Since α ≈ 1/137, we have
  a₀ ≈ 137 × λ̄_C.

Keep in mind that the full (or “standard”) electron Compton wavelength is
  λ_C = h/(m_e c) = 2π (ħ/(m_e c)) = 2πλ̄_C.
Thus, in terms of λ_C,
  a₀ = (λ̄_C)/α = (λ_C)/(2π α).

Now, let us compute the ratio a₀/λ_C:
  a₀/λ_C = 1/(2π α).
Plugging in α ≈ 1/137 and 2π ≈ 6.28:
  a₀/λ_C ≈ 1/(6.28 × 1/137) ≈ 137/6.28 ≈ 21.8.

That is, the Bohr radius is about 22 times the electron Compton wavelength if we adopt the standard definition of λ_C = h/(m_e c).

However, it is important to note that sometimes the term “electron Compton wavelength” is used colloquially to refer to the reduced Compton wavelength λ̄_C. In that case, one finds a₀/λ̄_C ≈ 1/α ≈ 137, which is on the order of 100. 

Now, looking at the answer choices:
 (a) 100 times larger  (b) 1000 times larger  (c) about the same
we see that the factor of 22 is not “about the same” (that would be a factor near unity) and is far from 1000. In an order‐of‐magnitude sense and given that in many contexts authors quote the Compton wavelength as the “reduced” one (or they are asking only for an approximate order-of-magnitude comparison), the Bohr radius is roughly 100 times larger than the electron “(reduced) Compton wavelength.”

Thus, the answer most nearly matching is option (a) 100 times larger.

Final answer:

\[
\boxed{ \text{(a) 100 times larger} }
\]
final_answers: \text{(a) 100 times larger}

We need to find the minimum (threshold) energy of a gamma photon that, when colliding with an electron at rest, can result in the creation of an electron–positron pair. The reaction is

  γ + e⁻ (at rest) → e⁻ + e⁻ + e⁺.

Notice that the final state contains three particles (two electrons and one positron). Since the process must conserve both energy and momentum, the threshold condition is when the final particles have just the minimum energy required – their rest mass energies – with as little kinetic energy as allowed by momentum conservation.

Step 1. Find the invariant (center-of-mass energy squared)

The 4‐momentum square (s) is invariant. In the lab frame the incoming photon has energy E (and momentum magnitude E, in units where c = 1) and the electron is at rest (energy m and zero momentum). Thus,
  s = (p_γ + p_e)² = p_γ² + 2p_γ·p_e + p_e².

Since the photon is massless, p_γ² = 0, and p_e² = m². In the lab frame (with p_e = (m, 0)):
  p_γ·p_e = E m.
Thus,
  s = m² + 2mE.

Step 2. Apply the threshold condition

At threshold, the final particles are produced with minimal (in fact, no excess) kinetic energy in the center-of-mass frame, so their total energy equals the sum of their rest energies. There are three particles (two electrons and one positron), each of mass m, so the total rest energy is 3m. Therefore the invariant mass squared must be

  s_threshold = (3m)² = 9m².

Step 3. Equate and solve for the photon energy

Setting s from the initial state equal to the threshold s:
  m² + 2m E_th = 9m².
Solve for E_th:
  2m E_th = 9m² – m² = 8m²,
  E_th = (8m²) / (2m) = 4m.

Thus, the threshold energy of the gamma-ray is 4m (rest-mass energy units). Including the speed of light explicitly, this is

  E_th = 4 m_e c².

For an electron with m_ec² ≃ 0.511 MeV, the threshold energy is approximately
  E_th ≃ 4 × 0.511 MeV ≃ 2.044 MeV.

Final Answer:

\[\boxed{E_{\text{th}} = 4 m_e c^2}\]
final_answers: E_{\text{th}} = 4 m_e c^2

solution:
Below is a step‐by‐step discussion of four topics selected from the list:

──────────────────────────────
1. J/ψ Particle

The J/ψ particle is a meson discovered in 1974 that sparked the “November Revolution” in particle physics. It is made up of a charm quark and its antiparticle (c c̄). Because of the heavy charm quarks, its mass is relatively high, and it exhibits a narrow width, meaning it decays more slowly than other hadronic resonances. Its discovery provided strong indirect evidence for the existence of the charm quark and led to a dramatic expansion in our understanding of quark structure and quantum chromodynamics (QCD).

──────────────────────────────
2. Neutral K Meson System (Including Regeneration of K_S)

The neutral kaon system involves the particles K⁰ and the anti-kaon K̄⁰, which for weak interactions are not mass eigenstates. Instead, they mix to form the short-lived K_S and the long-lived K_L states. A very interesting phenomenon associated with this system is “regeneration.” When a beam of K_L mesons passes through matter, interactions with the nuclei can convert part of the K_L beam into K_S mesons due to the differential absorptive properties of the medium in relation to the two components. This effect is a beautiful demonstration of quantum coherence and interference in particle physics, and it historically played a significant role in establishing the concept of CP violation in the neutral kaon system.

──────────────────────────────
3. The Two Types of Neutrino

Historically, two distinct neutrino types were identified: the electron neutrino (νₑ) and the muon neutrino (ν_μ). These neutrinos are associated with their corresponding charged leptons (the electron and the muon). Their separate existence is evidenced by the fact that in weak interactions (such as beta decay or muon decay), the conservation of lepton family number forbids, for instance, the conversion of a muon neutrino into an electron neutrino without violating observed conservation laws. The distinct behavior of these neutrinos underlies the structure of the weak interaction and led to the formulation of the V–A (vector-minus-axial vector) theory. (Later, a third neutrino, the tau neutrino, was also discovered, but the original “two types” remain central to early weak interaction theory.) 

──────────────────────────────
4. Abnormal Magnetic Moment of the Muon

The muon’s magnetic moment is a key precision observable. In Dirac theory one expects a gyromagnetic ratio (g) of exactly 2; however, quantum corrections from QED, hadronic contributions, and weak interactions introduce a small anomaly so that g = 2(1 + a_μ) with a_μ being the anomalous magnetic moment. Experimentally, a_μ has been measured to high precision, and there exists a slight discrepancy with the Standard Model prediction. This “abnormal” magnetic moment (often simply called the muon g–2 anomaly) is of intense interest because it might be a window into physics beyond the Standard Model – indicating contributions from new particles or forces that have yet to be discovered.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer in LaTeX Box:

\[
\boxed{
\begin{array}{l}
\textbf{J/}\psi\ \textbf{Particle: A bound state of charm and anti-charm quarks, its discovery in 1974 provided key evidence for the charm quark and validated QCD.} \\
\\
\textbf{Neutral }K\textbf{ Meson System: The K^0\mbox{-}\overline{K^0} mixing produces the CP eigenstates K_S and K_L; when passing through matter, regeneration effects produce a K_S component from a K_L beam.} \\
\\
\textbf{Two types of Neutrino: The distinct electron neutrino (}\nu_e\text{) and muon neutrino (}\nu_\mu\text{) are produced in association with their respective charged leptons, reflecting the separate conservation of lepton family numbers.} \\
\\
\textbf{Abnormal Magnetic Moment of the Muon: The measured deviation (g-2) of the muon from the Dirac value 2, arising from quantum loop corrections, hints at potential contributions from new physics beyond the Standard Model.}
\end{array}
}

We start with the fact that both decays happen via the same weak interaction, so that (ignoring small effects like radiative corrections) the decay rate for a three‐body leptonic decay scales as

  Γ ∝ G_F² m⁵.

Thus if we call the constant factor (which includes phase‐space and numerical factors) C (with C = G_F²/(192π³) in the usual tree‐level calculation), then

  Γ(μ → eν̄ν) = C m_μ⁵,
  Γ(τ → eν̄ν) = C m_τ⁵.

Since the muon decays almost exclusively via μ → eν̄ν, its entire width is given by the above expression. For the tau lepton, however, there are several decay channels; the given branching ratio for τ → eν̄ν is 16%, so

  BR(τ → eν̄ν) = Γ(τ → eν̄ν) / Γ_total(τ) = 0.16.

Thus, we may write

  Γ_total(τ) = Γ(τ → eν̄ν) / 0.16
         = C m_τ⁵ / 0.16.

But we know also that

  Γ(μ) = C m_μ⁵ = 1/τ_μ  with τ_μ = 2.2×10^–6 s.

Therefore,

  Γ_total(τ) = (m_τ⁵/m_μ⁵)(1/τ_μ)/0.16.

Taking the inverse gives the tau’s lifetime τ_τ:

  τ_τ = 1/Γ_total(τ) = τ_μ · 0.16 · (m_μ/m_τ)⁵.

Using the numbers
  m_μ = 106 MeV,
  m_τ = 1784 MeV,
we first compute the mass ratio:

  (m_μ/m_τ) = 106/1784 ≈ 0.0594.
  (m_μ/m_τ)⁵ ≈ (0.0594)⁵.

To estimate (0.0594)⁵, note that (1/16.83)⁵ = 1/(16.83)⁵. Since 1784/106 ≈ 16.83, we have:

  (m_μ/m_τ)⁵ = 1/(16.83)⁵.

A quick estimation for (16.83)⁵:

  log₁₀(16.83) ≈ 1.226  so  5×1.226 ≈ 6.13,
  thus (16.83)⁵ ≈ 10^(6.13) ≈ 1.35 × 10^6.
Hence,
  (m_μ/m_τ)⁵ ≈ 1/(1.35×10^6).

Now we can write:

  τ_τ = 2.2×10^–6 s · 0.16/(1.35×10^6)
      = (2.2 × 0.16)×10^–6 s / (1.35×10^6).

Calculate the numerator:

  2.2×0.16 = 0.352.

Thus,

  τ_τ ≈ 0.352×10^–6 s / 1.35×10^6 ≈ 0.352/1.35 ×10^(–6 –6) s
       ≈ 0.2607×10^–12 s
       ≈ 2.6×10^–13 s.

So (a) the estimated tau lifetime is on the order of 2.6×10^–13 seconds.

Now turn to (b). At a colliding beam accelerator operating at a center-of-mass energy E_em = 29 GeV (assuming the tau is produced with nearly that energy in the lab), the tau’s relativistic gamma factor is

  γ = E/m_τ = 29 GeV / (1.784 GeV) ≈ 16.26.

The mean lifetime in the lab is time-dilated:

  τ_lab = γ · τ_τ = 16.26 × 2.6×10^–13 s ≈ 4.23×10^–12 s.

Since the tau is highly relativistic (β ≈ 1), the average distance traveled before decay in the laboratory frame is

  d = c · τ_lab.

Taking c ≈ 3.0×10^8 m/s gives

  d ≈ 3.0×10^8 m/s × 4.23×10^–12 s ≈ 1.27×10^–3 m,
  or approximately 1.3 mm.

Note that if one instead uses our slightly rounded lifetime from the earlier estimate (say around 3.3×10^–13 s), one might get a lab lifetime of around 5.4×10^–12 s and a distance of ~1.6 mm, but here using our computed value of 2.6×10^–13 s gives an answer of roughly 1.3 mm. Depending on the precise numbers used, the answer will be of order 10^–3 m (a few mm or a little over a mm).

Thus, (b) a tau lepton with a lab energy of 29 GeV will travel on the order of one millimeter before decaying.

For clarity, our final answers are:

(a) τ_τ ≈ 2.6×10^–13 s,
(b) d ≈ 1.3×10^–3 m.

We now box the final answers:

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad \tau_{\tau} &\approx 2.6\times10^{-13}\,\text{s},\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad d &= c\,\tau_{\text{lab}} \approx 1.3\times10^{-3}\,\text{m}.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We wish to know what field strength is needed so that, within a time comparable to the electron’s orbital period around an atom (of order 10⁻¹⁶ sec), the electron is pulled out (“ionized”) of the atom.

A way to estimate this is to require that, under the electric field E the electron is accelerated fast enough so that it is displaced a distance of order the atomic size (i.e. the Bohr radius a₀) in a time t comparable to the orbital period.

Step 1. Write down the classical equation for displacement under constant acceleration:
  a₀ ≈ (½) a t²    (1)

Step 2. The acceleration a due to the electric field is given by:
  a = (eE/mₑ)
where
  e = 1.6×10⁻¹⁹ C    (electron charge)
  mₑ = 9.1×10⁻³¹ kg   (electron mass)

Step 3. Solve (1) for E:
  a₀ ≈ (½) (eE/mₑ) t²  ⟹ E ≈ (2 mₑ a₀)/(e t²)  (2)

Step 4. What should we take for t? The typical orbital time can be estimated using the Bohr model. In a rough way, the electron’s speed in the ground state is on the order of
  v ~ αc    (with α ≈ 1/137, c = 3×10⁸ m/s),
and the Bohr radius is
  a₀ ≈ 5.29×10⁻¹¹ m.
Thus, an order‐of‐magnitude estimate for the orbital period is:
  t ≈ (2π a₀)/v = 2πa₀/(αc).

Let’s estimate t numerically:
  v ≈ (3×10⁸ m/s)/137 ≈ 2.2×10⁶ m/s.
  t ≈ (2π × 5.3×10⁻¹¹ m)/(2.2×10⁶ m/s)
    ≈ (3.33×10⁻¹⁰ m)/(2.2×10⁶ m/s)
    ≈ 1.5×10⁻¹⁶ s.

Step 5. Now plug in the numbers into (2):
  E ≈ (2 × 9.1×10⁻³¹ kg × 5.3×10⁻¹¹ m) / (1.6×10⁻¹⁹ C × (1.5×10⁻¹⁶ s)²).

First, compute the numerator:
  Numerator = 2 × 9.1×10⁻³¹ × 5.3×10⁻¹¹ ≈ 9.65×10⁻⁴¹ kg·m.

Next, compute the denominator:
  (1.5×10⁻¹⁶ s)² = 2.25×10⁻³² s²,
  So Denom = 1.6×10⁻¹⁹ C × 2.25×10⁻³² = 3.6×10⁻⁵¹ C·s².

Thus:
  E ≈ (9.65×10⁻⁴¹) / (3.6×10⁻⁵¹)
    ≈ 2.68×10¹⁰ V/m.

Since our time estimate was rough (1.5×10⁻¹⁶ s is an order-of-magnitude estimate), our answer is roughly
  E ~ 10¹⁰ to 10¹¹ V/m.

In many simple treatments one argues that the field must do work over a distance a₀ comparable to the binding energy (∼13.6 eV for hydrogen). That is, setting
  e E a₀ ~ 13.6 eV.
Converting 13.6 eV to Joules:
  13.6 eV ≈ 2.18×10⁻¹⁸ J,
so one finds:
  E ≈ (2.18×10⁻¹⁸ J)/(1.6×10⁻¹⁹ C × 5.3×10⁻¹¹ m)
    ≈ (2.18×10⁻¹⁸)/(8.48×10⁻³⁰)
    ≈ 2.57×10¹¹ V/m.
This stronger field is what one would expect if one “overcomes” the binding energy in a static picture. In our case, however, we want the electron to leave the atom on the very short time scale of one orbital period, so our earlier estimate based on acceleration provides an electric field of order 10¹⁰–10¹¹ V/m.

Final Answer:
For an order-of-magnitude estimate, the electric field required is on the order of 10¹¹ V/m.

We can test parity conservation in the decay Λ⁰ → p + π⁻ by studying the angular distribution of the decay products relative to the Λ⁰ spin direction. Here is how the test works and when it might be of limited use:

Step 1. Measuring the Angular Distribution

When a Λ⁰ decays to a proton and a pion, its spin (if known) can provide a reference axis. The proton’s angular distribution in the Λ⁰ rest frame is generally written as

  W(θ) ∝ 1 + α cos θ,

where
 • θ is the angle between the proton’s momentum and the Λ⁰ polarization direction,
 • α is the decay (asymmetry) parameter.

Step 2. Parity Conservation and the Asymmetry Parameter

Under parity conservation the law of reflection (θ → π – θ, essentially a mirror reflection of the spatial coordinates) demands that the angular distribution be symmetric, that is, there should be no preferred direction. In other words, if parity were conserved, one would expect α = 0. A nonzero value of α signals a forward–backward asymmetry in the emission of the decay proton with respect to the polarization direction, implying parity violation.

Step 3. Practical Test

Thus, if one has a sample of Λ⁰ baryons with a known polarization, one can measure the angular distribution of the emitted protons. If the distribution is asymmetric (i.e., if α is found to be nonzero), then parity is violated in this decay.

Step 4. Circumstances That May Prevent the Usefulness of the Test

There are a couple of reasons why this test might not be useful:

1. Unpolarized Λ⁰:  
 If the Λ⁰’s are produced without a net polarization, then there is no preferred spin direction to correlate with the direction of the proton. In such a case, the angular distribution of decay products will be isotropic, making it impossible to extract information about parity violation.

2. Experimental Limitations:  
 If the detector does not have sufficient angular resolution or if there are systematic errors in determining the Λ⁰ spin direction, then the measurement of α may be ambiguous.  
 Also, if other processes or final state interactions obscure the simple angular correlation expected in the decay, then interpreting the results in terms of parity conservation may be complicated.

Step 5. Final Summary

The parity test relies on measuring an asymmetry in the angular distribution of the proton with respect to the Λ⁰ spin. A nonzero asymmetry parameter (α ≠ 0) indicates parity violation. However, if the Λ⁰ baryons are unpolarized or if experimental issues prevent a clean determination of the decay asymmetry, the test may not provide useful information about parity conservation.

In a parity-conserving decay, }W(\theta) \propto 1\text{ (i.e., } \alpha = 0\text{), but a nonzero } \alpha \text{ signals parity violation. However, if the Λ⁰s are unpolarized or experimental issues prevent accurate determination of the spin direction, the test cannot be effectively applied.}}
\]

We start by noting that in the decay of a pion (π) at rest into a muon (μ) and a neutrino (ν)

  π → μ + ν

energy and momentum are conserved. In the rest frame of the pion, the total momentum is initially zero. Since the neutrino is effectively massless and the muon is massive, the two final particles must be emitted back‐to‐back with equal magnitude of momentum.

For a two‐body decay in the rest frame of the parent particle (mass M), the momentum p of the daughter particles is determined by the formula

  p = (M² − m²) / (2M)
     (when one daughter is massless)

Here,
  M = m_π = 140 MeV/c² (mass of the pion)
  m = m_μ ≈ 105 MeV/c² (mass of the muon)

Thus, the muon momentum p_μ is given by

  p_μ = (m_π² − m_μ²) / (2 m_π)

Let’s compute this step by step:

1. Compute m_π² and m_μ²:
  m_π² = (140 MeV)² = 19600 (MeV)²
  m_μ² = (105 MeV)² ≈ 11025 (MeV)²

2. Subtract:
  m_π² − m_μ² = 19600 − 11025 = 8575 (MeV)²

3. Divide by (2 m_π):
  p_μ = 8575 / (2 × 140) = 8575 / 280 ≈ 30.625 MeV/c

Rounding, we get that the maximum (and unique) momentum of the muon is approximately 30 MeV/c. This corresponds to option (a).

Thus, the final answer is: 

\[
\boxed{30\, \text{MeV}/c}
\]

We start with a K-meson at rest that decays into a muon (mass m₁ = 106 MeV) and a neutrino (mass m₂ = 0). The total energy available is the rest energy of the K-meson, M = 494 MeV.

Step 1. Find the momentum of the decay products using conservation of momentum and energy. In a two‐body decay the momentum of each product in the rest frame of the decaying particle is given by

  p = (1/(2M))√[(M² – (m₁ + m₂)²)(M² – (m₁ – m₂)²)].

Since the neutrino is massless (m₂ = 0), this simplifies to

  p = (M² – m₁²)/(2M).

Plug in the numbers:
  M² – m₁² = 494² – 106².
Notice that this difference can be factored as
  (494 – 106)(494 + 106) = 388 × 600 = 232800 (MeV)²,
so
  p = 232800/(2 × 494) = 232800/988 ≈ 235.74 MeV.

Step 2. Compute the energy of the muon. Its total energy is given by
  E₁ = √(m₁² + p²).
Thus,
  E₁ = √(106² + (235.74)²)
     = √(11236 + 55652)
     = √66888 ≈ 258.64 MeV.

The kinetic energy of the muon is then
  T₁ = E₁ – m₁ ≈ 258.64 MeV – 106 MeV = 152.64 MeV.

Step 3. For the massless neutrino, the energy is equal to its momentum (with c = 1 in natural units):
  E₂ = p ≈ 235.74 MeV,
and since there is no rest mass, all of this energy is kinetic.

Thus, the kinetic energy of the neutrino is
  T₂ = E₂ ≈ 235.74 MeV.

Final Answer:
 The muon has a kinetic energy of approximately 152.6 MeV, and the neutrino has a kinetic energy of approximately 235.7 MeV.

\boxed{T_\mu \approx 152.6\ \text{MeV}, \quad T_\nu \approx 235.7\ \text{MeV}}
\]

We begin by noting that in the meson’s rest frame the decay produces two γ-rays of equal energy. If the rest energy of the meson is E₀, then each photon has energy E₀/2.

However, in the laboratory frame the meson is moving with speed v = βc. Due to relativistic Doppler shift, the photon energies will differ depending on whether the photon is emitted in the forward or backward direction relative to the motion of the meson. The Doppler formulas for the energies in the lab frame are:

  (1) For the forward-emitted photon:
   E₊ = (E₀/2) γ (1 + β)

  (2) For the backward-emitted photon:
   E₋ = (E₀/2) γ (1 − β)

where
  γ = 1/√(1 − β²).

We are given:
  E₊ = 96 MeV  and  E₋ = 48 MeV.

Step 1. Find β by dividing Equation (1) by Equation (2):

  [E₊/E₋] = [(E₀/2) γ (1 + β)] / [(E₀/2) γ (1 − β)] = (1 + β)/(1 − β)

Thus,
  (1 + β)/(1 − β) = 96/48 = 2

Solve for β:
  1 + β = 2 (1 − β)
  1 + β = 2 − 2β
  β + 2β = 2 − 1
  3β = 1  ⟹ β = 1/3

Step 2. Now find the rest energy E₀. Use either Equation (1) or Equation (2); here we use Equation (2):

  E₋ = (E₀/2) γ (1 − β)

Plug in E₋ = 48 MeV and β = 1/3:
  48 = (E₀/2) γ (1 − 1/3) = (E₀/2) γ (2/3)

Thus,
  48 = (E₀ γ (2))/(2·3) = (E₀ γ)/3

Solving for E₀, we obtain:
  E₀ γ = 144  ⟹  E₀ = 144/γ

Step 3. Compute γ for β = 1/3:
  γ = 1/√(1 − β²) = 1/√(1 − 1/9) = 1/√(8/9) = 3/√8

which can be simplified:
  γ = 3/(2√2) = (3√2)/4

Plug this value in:
  E₀ = 144 / ((3√2)/4) = 144 * (4/(3√2)) = (144*4)/(3√2) = (576)/(3√2) = 192/√2

It is often preferable to rationalize the denominator:
  E₀ = (192√2)/2 = 96√2 MeV

Step 4. Final Answers

(a) β = 1/3

(b) The rest energy of the meson is E₀ = 96 √2 MeV.

Thus, our final boxed answer is:

  \[
\boxed{\beta = \frac{1}{3} \quad \text{and} \quad E_0 = 96\sqrt{2}\,\text{MeV}}
\]

We wish to estimate the number of ^37Ar atoms made each day in the reaction

  ν + ^37Cl → ^37Ar + e⁻

taking as our detector about 4×10^5 liters of a chlorine‐rich liquid. (In the actual Davis experiment, a large tank of perchloroethylene – a “chlorine‐detector” – was used.) We must estimate the number of target ^37Cl atoms present and then “multiply” by the neutrino capture rate.

Below is one way to do the estimate:

──────────────────────────── Step 1. Estimating the Number of ^37Cl Atoms

Assume the following:
 (1) The detector uses a chemical such as perchloroethylene. (Sometimes the text writes “tetrachlorethylene” and “CCl₄”; the key point is that it is a chlorine‐rich liquid.) For our purposes we assume the liquid is perchloroethylene with formula C₂Cl₄.
 (2) Its density is about 1.62 g/cm³.
 (3) The volume of the detector is V = 4×10^5 liters. (Since 1 liter = 10³ cm³, the volume in cubic centimeters is)
   V = 4×10^5 L × 10³ cm³/L = 4×10^8 cm³.
 (4) Thus, its total mass is
   m = density × volume ≈ (1.62 g/cm³)(4×10^8 cm³) ≈ 6.48×10^8 g.
 (5) The molar mass of C₂Cl₄ is
   M = (2×12.0 + 4×35.45) g/mol ≈ (24.0 + 141.8) g/mol ≈ 165.8 g/mol.
 (6) The number of moles of C₂Cl₄ is
   n = m/M ≈ (6.48×10^8 g)/(165.8 g/mol) ≈ 3.91×10^6 mol.
 (7) The number of molecules is then
   N_mol = n×N_A ≈ 3.91×10^6 mol × 6.02×10^23 molec/mol ≈ 2.35×10^30 molecules.
 (8) Each molecule has 4 chlorine atoms, so the total number of Cl atoms is
   N_Cl ≈ 4×2.35×10^30 ≈ 9.41×10^30.
 (9) Natural chlorine consists of about 75.8% ^35Cl and about 24.2% ^37Cl. Therefore, the number of target ^37Cl atoms is
   N_target ≈ 0.242 × 9.41×10^30 ≈ 2.28×10^30.

──────────────────────────── Step 2. Estimating the Capture Rate

Neutrino–nucleus reactions are very rare. In solar neutrino detection experiments the reaction rate is traditionally given in “SNU” where

  1 SNU = 10^–36 captures per target atom per second.

Detailed solar model calculations give an expected capture rate on chlorine of roughly 8 SNU (the exact number depends on the solar model and neutrino oscillations, but our goal here is an order‐of‐magnitude estimate).

Thus, the capture rate per target atom is

  R_atom ≈ 8×10^–36 s^–1.

Then the total number of captures (i.e. ^37Ar atoms produced) per second in the target is

  R_total = N_target × (8×10^–36 s^–1)
     ≈ (2.28×10^30)(8×10^–36)
     ≈ 1.824×10^–5 s^–1.

Converting to a per‐day rate, note that one day has 86400 seconds. Therefore

  N_day = 1.824×10^–5 s^–1 × 86400 s/day ≈ 1.576 atoms/day.

In other words, roughly 1 to 2 ^37Ar atoms are produced each day in the detector.

──────────────────────────── Step 3. List of Assumptions

1. The detector is completely filled with perchloroethylene (a Cl‐rich liquid) of density ≈1.62 g/cm³ and volume ≈4×10^5 L.
2. The molecular weight of the liquid is taken to be ≈165.8 g/mol (i.e. for C₂Cl₄).
3. The natural abundance of chlorine isotopes is 75.8% ^35Cl and 24.2% ^37Cl.
4. The effective capture rate on ^37Cl, integrated over the solar neutrino energy spectrum, is assumed to be 8 SNU (8×10^–36 s^–1 per target atom).
5. It is assumed that every neutrino capture on ^37Cl produces a detectable ^37Ar nucleus and that there are no losses (i.e. extraction efficiencies are 100%).
6. We have neglected background processes and assumed that the composition and density of the liquid are uniform.

──────────────────────────── Step 4. How Can the Experiment Be Improved?

Several improvements can be made:

• Increase the target mass or use a liquid with an even higher chlorine density to increase the number of available ^37Cl atoms.
• Improve the chemical extraction and counting efficiency so that nearly all the produced ^37Ar nuclei are collected and identified.
• Reduce background signals (from radioactivity, cosmic rays, or other sources) by better shielding and purification.
• Increase the running time and/or improve the signal‐to‐noise ratio (for example by using improved radiochemical separation methods).
• Consider alternative detection media or techniques (such as real‐time detectors) that might have higher cross sections or allow continuous monitoring.

──────────────────────────── Final Answer

The estimated production is on the order of 1–2 ^37Ar atoms per day.

  \[\boxed{\text{About }1{-}2\,\text{atoms of }^{37}\text{Ar are produced per day.}}\]
