solution:
We can show the parity violation through the measurement of the angular distribution of the decay products. Let’s go through the details step by step.

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. Understanding the decay chain

(a) First, a π⁺ (spin-0) decays by
  π⁺ → μ⁺ + ν₍μ₎.
Because the pion is spinless, its decay is isotropic even though the decay process is governed by the weak interaction (which violates parity through its only left-handed couplings). However, the weak interaction gives a definite helicity to the produced muon (μ⁺) and neutrino. In fact, the V–A structure forces the muon to be produced in a highly polarized state.

(b) The muon then decays:
  μ⁺ → e⁺ + ν₍e₎ + ͞ν₍μ₎.
Since the muon is now polarized, the distribution of its decay products (the positrons, in particular) is not isotropic. This anisotropy is the observable quantity that carries the imprint of parity violation.

──────────────────────────────
Step 2. Observable Quantity: Angular Distribution

The key observable is the angular distribution of the positrons (e⁺) in the decay μ⁺ → e⁺ + ν₍e₎ + ͞ν₍μ₎ relative to the spin direction of the muon. Because the weak interaction preferentially couples to left-handed particles and right-handed antiparticles, the direction in which the e⁺ is emitted will be correlated with the muon’s spin.

A typical form for the angular distribution is given by:

  dN/dΩ ∝ 1 + α cos θ

or equivalently,

  dN/d(cos θ) ∝ 1 + α cos θ

where:
 • θ is the angle between the positron momentum vector and the muon polarization (spin) direction.
 • α is an asymmetry parameter (which is nonzero due to the V–A interaction), and its value is determined by the details of the decay matrix element.

A sketch of the distribution would show that more positrons are emitted in the “forward” direction (θ = 0) relative to the muon spin than in the “backward” direction (θ = π).

──────────────────────────────
Step 3. Which Process Violates Parity?

Although both the pion decay and the muon decay are mediated by weak interactions (which are known to violate parity), only the μ⁺ decay reveals the asymmetry when examined experimentally.

• In the case of π⁺ → μ⁺ + ν₍μ₎, the pion’s zero spin forces an isotropic distribution of the decay products. That is, even though the decay is due to a weak, parity-violating interaction, an isotropic distribution is forced by angular momentum conservation in a spin-0 system. (In short, there is no “observable” asymmetry in this decay.) 

• On the other hand, the polarized μ⁺, resulting from the pion decay, decays asymmetrically via μ⁺ → e⁺ + ν₍e₎ + ͞ν₍μ₎. The anisotropic distribution of the emitted e⁺ (relative to the muon spin) is a direct indicator of parity nonconservation (since a parity-conserving interaction would lead to an isotropic decay when the polarization is taken into account).

Thus, while both processes are weak and originate from the same underlying V–A interaction, only the muon decay exhibits an observable violation of parity.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer

(a) The measured quantity is the angular distribution of the emitted positrons (e⁺) relative to the spin direction of the decaying muon. It is typically given by a distribution of the form

  dN/d(cosθ) ∝ 1 + α cosθ,

where θ is the angle between the positron momentum and the muon spin direction, and α is a nonzero asymmetry parameter.

(b) Although both decays occur via the parity-violating weak interaction, the pion decay (π⁺ → μ⁺ + ν₍μ₎) is isotropic due to the pion’s zero spin and does not by itself reveal the violation. The parity violation is manifest in the muon decay (μ⁺ → e⁺ + ν₍e₎ + ͞ν₍μ₎), where the anisotropic distribution of the decay electrons (positrons) directly shows the parity nonconservation.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer in LaTeX Boxed Format
\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\;& \text{The observable is the angular distribution of the positrons relative to the muon spin, given by } \frac{dN}{d(\cos \theta)} \propto 1 + \alpha \cos \theta.\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\;& \text{Only the muon decay shows an observable parity violation because the polarized μ⁺ decays anisotropically,}\\
& \text{whereas the pion decay, being from a spin-0 particle, is isotropic despite its weak-interaction origin.}
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We will analyze each reaction carefully, checking the conservation laws (in particular, strangeness and isospin) that must be obeyed by strong (or electromagnetic) interactions. (Weak interactions could allow some of these violations, but in the context of such questions “allowed” means “allowed by the strong interaction”.)

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. Reaction (a): π⁻ + p → K⁻ + Σ⁺

• Check Strangeness:
 – The π⁻ is a non‐strange meson (S = 0).
 – The proton is non‐strange (S = 0).
 – The K⁻ (with quark content s\bar{u}) carries strangeness S = –1.
 – The Σ⁺ (with quark content uus) carries strangeness S = –1.

Thus, the final state has a total strangeness S = (–1) + (–1) = –2, while the initial state has S = 0. Since strong interactions conserve strangeness, this reaction is forbidden.

──────────────────────────────
Step 2. Reaction (b): d + d → ⁴He + π⁰

• Check Isospin:
 – The deuteron (d) is an isoscalar (I = 0).
 – Thus, the dd initial state has total isospin I = 0.
 – The ⁴He nucleus is also isoscalar (I = 0).
 – The π⁰ is one member of the isovector triplet (I = 1).

Since the final state is the combination of an I = 0 (⁴He) and an I = 1 (π⁰) particle, the overall isospin of the final state must be that of the pion, namely I = 1. This does not match the I = 0 of the initial state, so the reaction is forbidden by isospin conservation in strong interactions.

──────────────────────────────
Step 3. Reaction (c): K⁻ + p → Ξ⁻ + K⁺

• Check Strangeness:
 – The K⁻ (s\bar{u}) carries S = –1.
 – The proton has S = 0.
  => Total initial S = –1.
 – The Ξ⁻ (with quark content dss) carries S = –2.
 – The K⁺ (u\bar{s}) carries S = +1 (since an anti–strange quark contributes +1 in the usual convention).
  => Total final S = (–2) + (+1) = –1.

Other quantum numbers such as baryon number and charge are also balanced. Thus, reaction (c) is allowed.

──────────────────────────────
Step 4. Ratio of Cross Sections: 
 σ(p + p → π⁺ + d) / σ(n + p → π⁰ + d)

Examine the fact that both reactions lead to deuteron (d) formation. Recall:

• The deuteron has isospin I = 0.
• The pion has isospin I = 1.
• By isospin coupling, the final state (d + π) has total isospin I = 1.
• In the p + p case, the two protons (identical particles) necessarily combine to I = 1 (since with I₃ = +1 the only possibility is I = 1).
• In the n + p system one may form I = 1 or I = 0 states; however, only the I = 1 part (with the proper Clebsch–Gordan coefficients) will contribute to a final state of I = 1 when combined with the deuteron.

Using isospin symmetry and the Clebsch–Gordan coefficients for the transition, one finds that the amplitude for p+p → d+π⁺ is larger by a factor of √2 relative to that for n+p → d+π⁰. When taking the squares (since cross sections are proportional to the square of the amplitude), this gives:
 |Amplitude(pp → dπ⁺)|² / |Amplitude(np → dπ⁰)|² = 2.
Thus, the ratio of the cross sections is 2.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer

(a) π⁻ + p → K⁻ + Σ⁺ is forbidden because strangeness is not conserved (initial S = 0 vs. final S = –2).  
(b) d + d → ⁴He + π⁰ is forbidden because of isospin violation (initial I = 0 vs. final I = 1).  
(c) K⁻ + p → Ξ⁻ + K⁺ is allowed.  
Also, the cross section ratio is:

 σ(p+p → π⁺+d) / σ(n+p → π⁰+d) = 2.

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a) Forbidden (strangeness violation)}; \quad
\text{(b) Forbidden (isospin violation)}; \quad
\text{(c) Allowed}; \quad
\frac{\sigma(p+p \to \pi^+ + d)}{\sigma(n+p \to \pi^0 + d)} &= 2.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We wish to find the threshold kinetic energy for the reaction

  p + p → π⁺ + D  (1)

and then work out how an isotropic distribution in the center‐of‐mass (CM) appears in the laboratory frame.

Let us denote the masses by
  mₚ (proton), m_D (deuteron), m_π (pion).

───────────────────────────── 
Step (a): Threshold Kinetic Energy

In the laboratory we take one proton at rest and the other with total energy E₁ = T + mₚ (we use units in which c = 1). The invariant Mandelstam variable “s” is then

  s = (p₁ + p₂)² = mₚ² + mₚ² + 2mₚE₁ = 2mₚ² + 2mₚ(T + mₚ)
      = 2mₚT + 4mₚ².

At threshold the available total CM energy is just enough to produce the two final particles at rest relative to each other (in the CM) so that
  √s₍th₎ = m_D + m_π         (threshold condition)

Squaring we have
  (m_D + m_π)² = s₍th₎ = 2mₚT + 4mₚ².
Solving for T we obtain

  T = [(m_D + m_π)² – 4mₚ²] / (2mₚ).

Numerically, taking 
  mₚ = 938 MeV, m_D = 1874 MeV, m_π = 140 MeV,
first note that

  m_D + m_π = 1874 + 140 = 2014 MeV,
  so (m_D + m_π)² ≈ (2014)² ≈ 4,056,196 MeV².
Also, 4mₚ² = 4 × (938)². (A short calculation gives (938)² ≈ 879844 MeV², so 4mₚ² ≈ 3,519,376 MeV².)

Thus the numerator is
  4,056,196 – 3,519,376 = 536,820 MeV²,
and so

  T ≈ 536,820/(2×938) ≈ 536,820/1876 ≈ 286 MeV.
Thus the threshold kinetic energy in the laboratory is about 286 MeV.

───────────────────────────── 
Step (b): Transformation of Angular Distributions

We are now told that in the CM system the π⁺ is produced isotropically so that
  dP/dΩ* = 1/(4π),
where dΩ* = dφ* d(cosθ*). (The star always refers to quantities in the CM.)

To get the probability per unit solid angle in the laboratory (dΩ_lab = dφ_lab d(cosθ_lab)), one must relate dΩ* to dΩ_lab. In a Lorentz boost along (say) the z‐axis the relation between the polar angles is given by the standard aberration formula

  cosθ_lab = (β + cosθ*)/(1 + β cosθ*),
          (1)

where β is the velocity (in units of c) of the CM with respect to the laboratory frame. (For those who wish to include the full kinematics: the speed of the produced π⁺ in the laboratory, say β_π, and the magnitude of its momentum in the CM (p*) will enter when relating energies and momenta. In what follows we give the answer in “kinematic‐Jacobian” form.)

Since the reaction is azimuthally symmetric, we need only worry about the relation between cosθ* and cosθ_lab. One easily shows that

  d(cosθ_lab)/d(cosθ*) = (1 – β²)/(1 + β cosθ*)².
Thus

  d(cosθ*)/d(cosθ_lab) = (1 + β cosθ*)²/(1 – β²).

It is useful to write cosθ* in terms of cosθ_lab. Inverting (1) one finds

  cosθ* = (cosθ_lab – β)/(1 – β cosθ_lab).

Then one notes that
  1 + β cosθ* = 1 + β[(cosθ_lab – β)/(1 – β cosθ_lab)]
            = (1 – β²)/(1 – β cosθ_lab).

Thus the Jacobian becomes

  d(cosθ*)/d(cosθ_lab) = (1 – β²)²/(1 – β cosθ_lab)²·1/(1 – β²)
               = (1 – β²)/(1 – β cosθ_lab)².

Since the azimuthal angle is unchanged by the boost (so that dφ* = dφ_lab), one immediately obtains

  dΩ* = dφ* d(cosθ*) = dφ_lab d(cosθ_lab) × (1 – β²)/(1 – β cosθ_lab)²
       = dΩ_lab · (1 – β²)/(1 – β cosθ_lab)².

Now, the probability is invariant so that

  dP = (dP/dΩ*) dΩ* = (dP/dΩ_lab) dΩ_lab.
Thus the angular distribution in the lab is

  dP/dΩ_lab = (1/4π) · (dΩ*/dΩ_lab)
          = 1/(4π) · (1 – β²)/(1 – β cosθ_lab)².

This is the required normalized probability per unit solid angle in the laboratory. (In a more complete answer one might also show explicitly how the speed of the π⁺ in the lab (say, given by β_π) and the fixed CM momentum p* enter the relation between the energies; here, however, the essential Jacobian factor is exhibited.)

───────────────────────────── 
Step (c): Comments on the Apparent Singularity

Notice that the lab distribution

  dP/dΩ_lab = 1/(4π) · (1 – β²)/(1 – β cosθ_lab)²
has a denominator which becomes very small (and, in the idealized limit, even “diverges”) when 1 – β cosθ_lab → 0. This divergence occurs at a well‐defined, nonzero angle (since for β < 1, cosθ_lab = 1/β is less than 1). In 2–body endothermic reactions the reason that the laboratory angular distribution can be “singular” (i.e. sharply peaked) at a finite angle is exactly that the Lorentz transformation from an isotropic distribution in the CM involves a Jacobian which may vanish for a particular value of cosθ_lab. In physical terms, many different emission angles in the CM are “bunched together” into a very small interval of lab angles. (In a real experiment, finite resolution and other “smearing” effects remove the actual singularity.) This focusing of the angular distribution is one of the characteristic “kinematic effects” when one boosts from the CM to the lab in reactions of this kind.

───────────────────────────── 
Final Answer

(a) The threshold kinetic energy in the lab is

  T = [ (m_D + m_π)² – 4 mₚ² ]/(2 mₚ).

Numerically this is approximately

  T ≈ 286 MeV.

(b) If the π⁺ is produced isotropically in the CM (so that dP/dΩ* = 1/(4π)), then the differential probability per unit solid angle in the lab is

  dP/dΩ_lab = 1/(4π) · (1 – β²)/(1 – β cosθ_lab)².

(c) The “singularity” (or very sharp peaking) in dP/dΩ_lab at a finite lab angle occurs because the Jacobian for the transformation between CM and lab angles (namely, d(cosθ*)/d(cosθ_lab) = (1 – β²)/(1 – β cosθ_lab)²) can vanish for a particular value of cosθ_lab. In other words, even though the CM emission is isotropic, the Lorentz boost “focuses” many CM directions into a narrow lab angular interval; this is the kinematic origin of the singular behavior seen in 2–body endothermic reactions.

─────────────────────────────

\quad\text{(so that numerically }T\approx286\text{ MeV)}.\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad &\frac{dP}{d\Omega_{\rm lab}}=\frac{1}{4\pi}\,\frac{1-\beta^{2}}{(1-\beta\cos\theta_{\rm lab})^{2}}\\[1mm]
\text{(c)}\quad &\text{The divergence at a finite } \theta_{\rm lab} \text{ is due to the Jacobian } 
\frac{d(\cos\theta^{*})}{d(\cos\theta_{\rm lab})}=\frac{1-\beta^{2}}{(1-\beta\cos\theta_{\rm lab})^{2}},

We start with the standard Compton scattering process for a photon of wavelength λ scattering off an electron at rest. Energy–momentum conservation together with quantum mechanics leads to the well‐known Compton relation.

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. (a) Derive λ′

The Compton wavelength shift is given by

  Δλ = λ′ − λ = (h/(mₑc)) (1 – cos θ),

where
  h  = Planck’s constant,
  mₑ = electron mass, and
  c  = speed of light.

Thus, the wavelength of the scattered photon is

  λ′ = λ + (h/(mₑc))(1 – cos θ).

──────────────────────────────
Step 2. (b) Compute the Kinetic Energy of the Recoiled Electron

Using energy conservation, the total energy before the collision (photon energy plus the rest energy of the electron) equals the total energy after scattering. The initial photon energy is

  E = hc/λ.

After the collision the photon has energy

  E′ = hc/λ′

and the electron (starting from rest) gains kinetic energy K (its rest energy mₑc² is unchanged in the energy balance because it is included on both sides). Thus, energy conservation gives

  hc/λ + mₑc² = hc/λ′ + mₑc² + K.

Cancel mₑc² on both sides to obtain

  K = hc/λ – hc/λ′.

Using the answer from part (a) we know that λ′ = λ + (h/(mₑc))(1 – cos θ). Therefore, we have

  K = hc(1/λ – 1/(λ + (h/(mₑc))(1 – cos θ))).

This is an acceptable answer. It is sometimes more illuminating to express K in terms of the initial photon energy E = hc/λ. To do that, write

  λ′ = λ + (h/(mₑc))(1 – cos θ)  ⟹  1/λ′ = 1/λ × 1/(1 + (h/(mₑcλ))(1 – cos θ)).

Since h c/λ = E and h c/(mₑcλ) = E/(mₑc²), we can write

  K = E – E/(1 + (E/(mₑc²))(1 – cos θ))
     = E [1 – 1/(1 + (E/(mₑc²))(1 – cos θ))].

A little algebra gives an alternate form:

  K = E²(1 – cos θ) / [mₑc² + E(1 – cos θ)].

Thus, the kinetic energy of the recoil electron can be expressed either as

  K = (hc/λ) – (hc/(λ + (h/(mₑc))(1 – cos θ)))           [form 1]

or equivalently as

  K = E²(1 – cos θ) / [mₑc² + E(1 – cos θ)]   with E = hc/λ      [form 2].

──────────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) The wavelength of the scattered photon is

  λ′ = λ + (h/(mₑc))(1 – cos θ).

(b) The kinetic energy of the recoil electron is

  K = (hc/λ) – (hc/(λ + (h/(mₑc))(1 – cos θ)))
    = E²(1 – cos θ)/[mₑc² + E(1 – cos θ)]        (with E = hc/λ).

──────────────────────────────

We can understand the problem step by step.

──────────────────────────────
Step (a): Why is μ⁺ → e⁺ + γ so rare?

In the Standard Model (SM) the separate lepton flavors (electron number and muon number) are conserved, and there is no tree‐level interaction that allows a muon to directly “transform” into an electron plus a photon. (Only after neutrino mixing is introduced does one have a nonzero, but extremely suppressed, μ → eγ amplitude.) In fact, the amplitude is suppressed by the Glashow‐Iliopoulos‐Maiani (GIM) mechanism along with the very small neutrino masses. Therefore, the observed (or expected) branching ratio is extremely small. That is, it is the conservation – or nearly exact conservation – of lepton flavor (here, muon and electron numbers) that is responsible for the suppression of this decay.

──────────────────────────────
Step (b): How should the detectors be arranged and what is the tell‐tale signal?

For a μ⁺ decaying at rest via the two-body process μ⁺ → e⁺ + γ, energy and momentum conservation require that the positron and the photon share the muon mass energy roughly equally (apart from the small electron mass) and are emitted back‐to‐back. Hence one would place two NaI (sodium iodide) crystal detectors on opposite sides of the stopping target. One crystal would be positioned so as to detect the positrons while the other would catch the gamma rays. The clear experimental signature of the μ → eγ event would be a coincident detection (within a short time window) of two energy deposits equal in magnitude to roughly half the muon mass (i.e. about 52–55 MeV each) and with the two signals coming from opposite directions.

──────────────────────────────
Step (c): How to distinguish radiative muon decays (background) from the signal?

The background process, μ⁺ → e⁺ + νₑ + ν̄_μ + γ, is a four-body decay, and the neutrinos carry away a variable amount of energy and momentum. As a result, in such events the energies of the positron and the photon are not fixed at the values expected for a two-body decay and they are not exactly back‐to‐back. In an actual experiment one would distinguish the signal from these background events by requiring that:
  • the positron and photon each carry nearly a fixed energy (close to half the muon mass), and
  • they emerge in opposite directions (i.e. the opening angle is near 180°) with the total energy summing to the muon mass.
Any deviation in energy or angle signals an “extra” particle’s presence (the neutrinos), thereby identifying an event as background.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer

\[
\boxed{
\begin{array}{l}
\text{(a) The decay is suppressed because of the accidental conservation of lepton flavor (or, equivalently,} \\
\quad \text{by the GIM mechanism with tiny neutrino masses). In the SM, separate conservation of muon and electron} \\
\quad \text{numbers forbids a tree‐level μ \to e\gamma decay.} \\
\\
\text{(b) One places two energy‐sensitive (NaI) detectors on opposite sides of the stopping target so that,} \\
\quad \text{when a μ decays at rest, the e⁺ and γ emerge back‐to‐back. A μ \to eγ event is signaled by the} \\
\quad \text{simultaneous deposition of the full energy (close to half the muon mass in each detector) and opposite} \\
\quad \text{directions of the two signals.} \\
\\
\text{(c) In the radiative decay background μ \to eν\bar{ν}γ, the neutrinos carry off part of the energy and momentum;} \\
\quad \text{thus the e⁺ and γ do not have fixed energies nor emerge exactly back‐to‐back. By demanding that the detected} \\
\quad \text{e⁺ and γ have the expected energies and angular correlation of a two-body decay, one can distinguish} \\
\quad \text{signal events from the three (or four) body background events.}
\end{array}
}
\]

solution:
We will show that if one tries to “make” these decays occur, some fundamental quantum number or symmetry would be violated. (In what follows “conservation law” means an exact symmetry of the Standard Model.)

Let’s discuss each case in turn.

───────────────────────────── 
1) n → p + e⁻
 
A free neutron does actually decay in nature—but its dominant decay is

  n → p + e⁻ + ν̄ₑ

with an antineutrino in the final state. (That extra particle is essential.) Notice that in the “decay” written above there is an electron, which carries lepton number L = +1, whereas the neutron and proton (both baryons) have L = 0. Hence if one tried to have
  n → p + e⁻ 
the overall lepton number would change from 0 to +1. (By convention the anti‐neutrino, having L = –1, makes the balance work in ordinary β–decay.) 

Thus, the decay n → p + e⁻ is forbidden by conservation of lepton number.

───────────────────────────── 
2) n → π⁺ + e⁻

Now, the neutron is a baryon with baryon number B = 1, but the pion is a meson (B = 0) and the electron is a lepton (B = 0). Therefore the net baryon number in the final state would be 0, while it is 1 initially.

Thus, this process is forbidden by the conservation of baryon number.

───────────────────────────── 
3) n → p + π⁻

Let us compare the rest masses. The free‐neutron mass is about 939.57 MeV. The proton mass is about 938.27 MeV, and the charged pion mass is about 139.57 MeV. If one writes

  m(p) + m(π⁻) ≈ 938.27 MeV + 139.57 MeV ≈ 1077.84 MeV

this is far above the neutron’s rest mass. Energy–momentum conservation requires that the mass of the decaying particle be at least as big as the total rest–mass of its products. Since

  mₙ < mₚ + m(π⁻)
 
this decay cannot occur. (Even if one tried to “borrow” some momentum there is simply not enough rest–energy available.)

Thus, the decay n → p + π⁻ is forbidden by energy–conservation (or “mass–energy conservation”).

───────────────────────────── 
4) n → p + γ

In contrast to the previous examples, both energy and momentum (four–momentum) can be conserved here. In the rest frame of the neutron one can “solve” the conservation laws: with

  pₙ = (mₙ, 0),
  pₚ = (Eₚ, 𝐩),
  k = (|𝐩|, –𝐩)
 
energy conservation leads to

  mₙ = √(mₚ² + |𝐩|²) + |𝐩|  →  |𝐩| = (mₙ² – mₚ²)/(2mₙ).

That has a nonzero solution because mₙ > mₚ.

So what forbids n → p + γ? The answer is that a free (isolated) particle cannot “spontaneously” emit a single real photon. (This is analogous to the statement that a free electron cannot radiate even though m(electron) is constant—in order for a charged particle to radiate, it must be accelerated by an external force or be part of a bound system with discrete energy levels.) More formally, if one attempts to write an amplitude for a free fermion making a radiative transition into another on–shell fermion plus a photon, one finds that the matrix element vanishes (once one enforces the Ward identity and the on–shell conditions); one says that the process is kinematically “closed” despite the existence of a solution for the momenta.

Thus, the decay n → p + γ is forbidden by energy–momentum conservation (or equivalently, by the fact that an isolated, on–shell particle cannot radiate a single real photon without the aid of an external field or a third particle to share the recoil).

───────────────────────────── 
Final Answers

1. n → p + e⁻ is forbidden by conservation of lepton number.

2. n → π⁺ + e⁻ is forbidden by conservation of baryon number.

3. n → p + π⁻ is forbidden by energy (mass–energy) conservation.

4. n → p + γ is forbidden because a free (isolated) particle cannot emit a single real photon while conserving energy and momentum.

───────────────────────────── 

Final Answer in Boxed Latex:

\[
\boxed{
\begin{array}{rcl}
n\to p+e^- &:& \text{violates lepton number conservation (net } L: 0\to +1\text{)} \\
n\to\pi^++e^- &:& \text{violates baryon number conservation (} B: 1\to 0\text{)} \\
n\to p+\pi^- &:& \text{violates energy (mass--energy) conservation} \\
n\to p+\gamma &:& \text{is forbidden because a free particle cannot radiate a single photon while conserving energy–momentum.}
\end{array}
}
\]

solution:
We will examine each reaction in detail, checking conservation laws (energy–momentum, electric charge, baryon and lepton number, etc.) and symmetry constraints (especially C‐parity) to decide whether the reaction is allowed and, if so, via which interaction.

──────────────────────────────
1. π⁻ + p → π⁰ + n

Step 1. Check conservation laws:
• Electric charge: (–1 + +1) = 0 on the left, (0 + 0) = 0 on the right.
• Baryon number: p (B = +1) and n (B = +1) cancel with no baryon number change.
• Isospin etc.: This reaction is well known.

Step 2. Interaction type:
Because all conserved quantum numbers are satisfied and the reaction is very fast (typical time scale ~10⁻²³ sec), it proceeds via the strong interaction.

Final: Allowed; strong interaction.

──────────────────────────────
2. π⁰ → γ + γ + γ

Step 1. Check C‐parity:
The π⁰ has intrinsic C-parity C = +1 (this is established from its quark content and its decays). A photon has “intrinsic” C eigenvalue –1. In a system of three photons the overall C is
  (–1)³ = –1.
Thus the final state would have C = –1, which does not match the initial C = +1.
(One may also note that electromagnetic interactions conserve C–parity.)

Step 2. Conclusion:
This decay is forbidden by C–parity conservation in electromagnetic processes (besides other complications).

──────────────────────────────
3. π⁰ → γ + γ

Step 1. Same conservation laws:
• C–parity: Two photons have overall C = (–1)² = +1 (provided their relative orbital angular momentum is even, which is the case for the dominant decay mode).
• Energy–momentum, parity, etc. are also conserved.

Step 2. Interaction type:
This decay is driven by the electromagnetic interaction (more precisely by the chiral anomaly in QCD, but it is an electromagnetic decay).

Final: Allowed; electromagnetic (anomalous) decay.

──────────────────────────────
4. π⁺ → μ⁺ + ν_μ

Step 1. Check quantum numbers:
• Electric charge: π⁺ has charge +1; μ⁺ is +1 and the neutrino is neutral.
• Lepton number: Initially 0. In the final state, muon neutrino (ν_μ) carries lepton number +1, and μ⁺ (being the anti-particle of μ⁻) carries lepton number –1. The net is 0.
• Other quantum numbers (spin, etc.) match under the weak interaction.

Step 2. Interaction type:
This is the standard decay of the charged pion via the charged-current weak interaction.

Final: Allowed; weak interaction.

──────────────────────────────
5. π⁺ → μ⁺ + \bar{ν}_μ

Step 1. Check lepton number:
• For the charged pion (π⁺), the overall lepton number is 0.
• In the proposed final state, μ⁺ has lepton number –1 and the muon antineutrino (\bar{ν}_μ) also carries lepton number –1. The total is –2, which does not conserve lepton number.

Step 2. Conclusion:
This decay is forbidden by lepton number conservation (more generally, by the structure of the weak charged current, which produces a charged anti-lepton paired with the corresponding neutrino, not its antiparticle).

──────────────────────────────
6. p + \bar{p} → Λ⁰ + \bar{Λ}⁰

Step 1. Check conservation laws:
• Baryon number: p (B = +1) + \bar{p} (B = –1) gives 0; Λ⁰ (B = +1) + \bar{Λ}⁰ (B = –1) gives 0.
• Charge: p is +1 and \bar{p} is –1; Λ⁰ and \bar{Λ}⁰ are neutral.
• Other quantum numbers (strangeness, etc.) can be produced if the available energy is sufficient.

Step 2. Interaction type:
p\bar{p} annihilation and subsequent production of a baryon–antibaryon pair is a typical strong interaction process.

Final: Allowed; strong interaction.

──────────────────────────────
7. p + \bar{p} → γ

Step 1. Kinematics and conservation:
• A single real photon is massless and always travels at the speed of light. In the center‐of‐mass frame of p and \bar{p} (which are massive and can be brought to rest overall), conservation of four–momentum cannot be satisfied by a single on–shell photon.
• Furthermore, even if one entertains symmetry arguments, a single photon does not allow one to conserve angular momentum in general.
• (Also note, in many annihilation processes at rest, at least 2 photons are required in order to conserve momentum and angular momentum.)

Step 2. Conclusion:
The reaction is forbidden by energy–momentum conservation (and angular momentum/spin considerations).

──────────────────────────────
Final Answers Summary:

1. π⁻ + p → π⁰ + n: Allowed; strong interaction.  
2. π⁰ → γ + γ + γ: Forbidden – violates C–parity conservation.  
3. π⁰ → γ + γ: Allowed; electromagnetic (anomalous) decay.

solution:
We start by analyzing the decay process when the heavy neutrino (mass m_H) is essentially at rest in the current epoch. The decay is

  ν_H → ν_L + γ.

Because the decaying heavy neutrino is at rest, conservation of energy and momentum will force the final decay products to have well‐defined energies and momenta.

————————————
Step (a): Show that the photon is monoenergetic and find its energy

Since the heavy neutrino is initially at rest its energy is just its rest mass m_H (using natural units in which c = 1). Let the energy of the photon be E_γ, and let the momentum of the neutrino, which must be equal in magnitude to the photon’s momentum (since momentum must be conserved), be p. Note that for a photon p = E_γ.

For the light neutrino ν_L (mass m_L) the energy will be

  E_νL = √(p² + m_L²) = √(E_γ² + m_L²).

Energy conservation gives

  m_H = E_γ + √(E_γ² + m_L²).

We now solve for E_γ. First, rearrange to obtain

  m_H − E_γ = √(E_γ² + m_L²).

Square both sides to eliminate the square root:

  (m_H − E_γ)² = E_γ² + m_L²
  m_H² − 2m_H E_γ + E_γ² = E_γ² + m_L².

The E_γ² terms cancel, leaving:

  m_H² − 2 m_H E_γ = m_L²      (1)

Solve for E_γ:

  2 m_H E_γ = m_H² − m_L²,
  E_γ = (m_H² − m_L²) / (2 m_H).

Thus, the photon is monoenergetic (each decay produces a photon of the same energy) with energy

  E_γ = (m_H² − m_L²) / (2 m_H).

————————————
Step (b): Evaluate for m_L ≪ m_H and compute spectral regime for m_H = 50 eV

For m_L ≪ m_H we have m_L² ≪ m_H² so the expression simplifies to:

  E_γ ≈ m_H² / (2 m_H) = m_H / 2.

Thus, the photon energy is approximately m_H/2. Substituting m_H = 50 eV gives

  E_γ ≈ 50 eV / 2 = 25 eV.

A photon of 25 eV lies in the extreme ultraviolet (EUV) part of the spectrum (since typical UV photon energies range between about 3 eV and 100 eV).

————————————
Step (c): Qualitative change if the lifetime is short compared to the age of the Universe

If the heavy neutrinos decay when the Universe is much younger (short lifetime compared to the current age) and are still “cold” (i.e. they have negligible kinetic energy at the time of decay), then each decay still produces a monoenergetic photon of energy given by the formula above in the neutrino’s rest frame. However, because these decays occur at various epochs in the early Universe, the photons will be substantially redshifted by cosmic expansion before they are observed today. As a result:

 • The observed energies of the photons will be lower than the emission energy.
 • Instead of a sharp line at 25 eV, the decay photons would be spread out over a range of lower energies, with the line being broadened by the redshift distribution corresponding to the cosmic time of decay.

Thus, the decay signal would not appear as a narrow spectral line in the laboratory frame but as a redshifted and broadened feature.

————————————
Final Answers

(a) The photon energy is 
  E_γ = (m_H² − m_L²)/(2 m_H).

(b) For m_L ≪ m_H, E_γ ≈ m_H/2. With m_H = 50 eV, one expects photons of ≈ 25 eV, which lie in the extreme ultraviolet (EUV) range.

(c) If the lifetime were short (with decays occurring early), then although the photons still are produced monoenergetically in the neutrino rest frame, the expansion of the Universe would redshift and broaden the line. Consequently, the observed signal today would cover a range of lower energies rather than a sharp line.

solution:
Let’s break down the answer step by step.

1. General Properties of Neutrinos and Antineutrinos

• Neutrality and Mass:
  – Neutrinos and antineutrinos carry no electric charge.
  – They have extremely small masses (long believed to be zero, but neutrino oscillation experiments show that they have nonzero, though very tiny, masses).

• Interaction:
  – They interact only via the weak nuclear force (and gravitationally), making them notoriously difficult to detect as their cross sections for interaction are very low.
  – This weak interaction is manifested in processes like beta decay and inverse beta decay.

• Spin and Helicity:
  – Both neutrinos and antineutrinos are spin-½ fermions.
  – In the Standard Model, observed neutrinos are produced with left-handed helicity, whereas antineutrinos are produced with right-handed helicity.

• Flavors:
  – There are three known “flavors” corresponding to the charged leptons: electron neutrino (νₑ), muon neutrino (ν_μ), and tau neutrino (ν_τ) and their corresponding antineutrinos.
  – Neutrino flavor conversion (oscillations) implies that neutrinos have a more complex mass structure than previously thought.

2. Physical Motivation for the Original Postulate

The neutrino was originally postulated by Wolfgang Pauli in 1930. The key motivation was the observation in beta decay:
  – In beta decay, a nucleus emits an electron (or positron) and what was then thought to be just the electron (or positron) should carry away energy and momentum.
  – However, the electron energy spectrum was found to be continuous, not discrete, implying that some energy, momentum, and angular momentum were “missing” if only the electron and the recoiling nucleus were considered.
  – To preserve the conservation laws (energy, momentum, and angular momentum), Pauli proposed the existence of an additional neutral, light particle that was not being detected at that time. This particle later became known as the neutrino (originally “neutron,” but later renamed when the actual neutron was discovered).

3. First Direct Detection of the Neutrino

Direct detection came much later:
  – In the mid-1950s, Frederick Reines and Clyde Cowan designed an experiment to detect antineutrinos produced by nuclear reactors.
  – They used the inverse beta decay reaction: an antineutrino (ν̄ₑ) interacts with a proton (p) to produce a positron (e⁺) and a neutron (n), expressed as
    ν̄ₑ + p → e⁺ + n.
  – The positron quickly annihilates with an electron, producing gamma rays, while the neutron is captured after a short delay, also emitting gamma rays.
  – The key to detection was the “delayed coincidence” technique—detecting the prompt gamma rays from positron annihilation followed by the delayed gamma rays from neutron capture.
  – The successful detection of these signals provided the first direct experimental proof of the neutrino’s existence.

\quad\bullet\ \text{They interact only via the weak force (and gravitation), making their detection challenging.}\\[2mm]
\quad\bullet\ \text{They exist in three flavors (electron, muon, and tau) with corresponding helicity properties:}\\
\qquad\text{neutrinos are left-handed and antineutrinos are right-handed.}\\[2mm]
\textbf{Original Postulate Motivation:}\\[1mm]
\quad\bullet\ \text{The neutrino was postulated to explain the continuous energy spectrum of electrons in beta decay.}\\[1mm]
\quad\bullet\ \text{Conservation of energy, momentum, and angular momentum demanded an additional, undetected particle.}\\[2mm]
\textbf{First Direct Detection:}\\[1mm]
\quad\bullet\ \text{The 1956 Reines-Cowan experiment at a nuclear reactor detected antineutrinos via the inverse beta decay reaction:}\\[1mm]
\qquad\nūₑ + p \rightarrow e⁺ + n,\\[1mm]
\quad\bullet\ \text{using a delayed coincidence technique to identify the prompt and delayed gamma-ray signals.}
\end{array}
}
\]

solution:
We are told that the charged–current neutrino–nucleon cross section grows linearly with the neutrino energy, and that roughly one in every 10^6 neutrinos (with Eν = 1000 GeV) interacts in the detector. In other words, the interaction probability over a detector of thickness L must be

  P = n σ L ≈ 10^(-6).

Here the number density of nuclei is given by

  n = (ρ / ⟨A⟩) N_A,

where
  ρ ≈ 5 g/cm³,
  ⟨A⟩ = 20 g/mol (the mean atomic mass), and
  N_A ≈ 6.022 × 10^(23) nuclei/mol.

Step 1. Find n:
  n = (5 g/cm³) / (20 g/mol) × (6.022 × 10^(23) nuclei/mol)
    = (0.25 mol/cm³) × (6.022 × 10^(23) nuclei/mol)
    ≈ 1.5055 × 10^(23) nuclei/cm³.

Step 2. Estimate σ. A common approximate form for the high–energy neutrino–nucleon cross section is:
  σ(Eν) ≈ 10^(–38) cm²/GeV × Eν.

Thus for Eν = 1000 GeV,
  σ ≈ 10^(–38) cm²/GeV × 1000 GeV = 10^(–35) cm².

Step 3. The probability for a neutrino to interact in a detector of length L (in cm) is
  P = n σ L.
We want P = 10^(–6). Thus,
  L = (10^(–6)) / (n σ).

Plug in the numbers:
  L = (10^(–6)) / (1.5055 × 10^(23) cm^(–3) × 10^(–35) cm²)
    = (10^(–6)) / (1.5055 × 10^(–12) cm^(–1))
    ≈ 0.664 × 10^(6) cm
    ≈ 6.64 × 10^(5) cm.

Step 4. Convert L to meters or kilometers:
  1 m = 100 cm so L ≈ 6.64 × 10^(5) cm / 100 = 6640 m,
or approximately 6.6 km (which is closest to 6 km among the given choices).

Thus, the answer is about 6 km.

Final Answer:
  \[\boxed{6\,\text{km}}\]

We wish to list, for each particle, one decay mode whose branching ratio is greater than about 5%. (In some cases the chosen channel is overwhelmingly dominant.) Note that there may be several acceptable answers; the following is one acceptable set.

Step‐by‐step, we choose a decay mode for each particle:

1. Neutron (n):  
The free neutron decays via beta decay  
  n → p + e⁻ + (anti‑νₑ)  
with a branching ratio essentially 100%.

2. Charged pion (π⁺):  
The dominant mode is  
  π⁺ → μ⁺ + νₘᵤ  
(with over 99% branching ratio).

3. Neutral rho meson (ρ⁰):  
The ρ⁰ almost always decays into two pions, so one has  
  ρ⁰ → π⁺ + π⁻.

4. Neutral kaon (K⁰):  
There are two mass–eigenstates (K_S and K_L). For example, the short–lived state decays dominantly via  
  K_S → π⁺ + π⁻,  
which has a branching ratio of about 69%.

5. Lambda baryon (Λ⁰):  
A common decay mode is  
  Λ⁰ → p + π⁻  
with a branching ratio of about 64%.

6. Delta++ resonance (Δ⁺⁺):  
The Δ⁺⁺ decays nearly 100% of the time as  
  Δ⁺⁺ → p + π⁺.

7. Muon (μ⁻):  
The muon decays via the weak interaction as  
  μ⁻ → e⁻ + νₘᵤ + (anti‑νₑ)  
(with practically 100% branching ratio).

8. Phi meson (φ):  
Its main decay mode is to charged kaons  
  φ → K⁺ + K⁻  
(with a branching ratio near 49%).

9. Omega baryon (Ω⁻):  
A typical decay is  
  Ω⁻ → Λ⁰ + K⁻  
with a branching ratio of roughly 68%.

10. J/ψ meson (J/ψ):  
A non‐trivial electromagnetic decay, with a branching ratio of about 6%, is  
  J/ψ → e⁺ + e⁻.  
(Alternatively one may choose J/ψ → μ⁺ + μ⁻.)

Thus, one acceptable set of answers is:

solution:
We can understand many “forbidden” or “suppressed” processes by asking which conservation law (or approximate symmetry) is being violated (or is “inefficient” in providing an amplitude) in a given process. In the answers below we briefly explain the reason for each case.

1. p + n → p + Λ⁰  
 • The Λ⁰ is a strange baryon (its “strangeness” is nonzero), whereas the initial proton and neutron carry no strangeness. In a strong interaction the strangeness quantum number is conserved. Hence, to produce a Λ⁰ from a p–n collision one would have to create net strangeness, which is not allowed by the strong‐interaction rules. (It could occur via the weak interaction but then its rate is enormously suppressed.)

2. K⁺ → π⁺ + π⁻ + π⁺ + π⁻ + π⁺ + π⁰  
 • The mass of the K⁺ (about 494 MeV) is far too low to produce six pions (each with a mass around 135–140 MeV). Thus there is no available phase space and the decay is kinematically forbidden (energy–momentum conservation).

3. K̄⁰ → π⁻ + e⁺ + νₑ  
 • This is an example of a semileptonic weak decay. Here the change in quark flavor (and the change in strangeness, ΔS = 1) occurs via the charged‐current weak interaction. (In other words, the process does not occur via strong or electromagnetic interactions but only by the weak force – and the weak coupling is much smaller.)

4. Λ⁰ → K⁰ + π⁰  
 • The Λ⁰ is a baryon (baryon number = 1) while both the K⁰ and π⁰ are mesons (baryon number = 0). In any allowed reaction baryon number must be conserved. So this decay is forbidden because it would violate baryon–number conservation.

5. π⁺ → e⁺ + νₑ (relative to π⁺ → μ⁺ + ν_μ)  
 • Although both are allowed weak decays, the V–A character of the weak charged current forces the amplitude to be proportional to the mass of the final charged lepton. This helicity (or chiral) suppression makes the decay to e⁺ + νₑ very much smaller than the decay to μ⁺ + ν_μ. (Experimentally the π⁺ → e⁺ + νₑ branching ratio is about 1.2 × 10⁻⁴ of the μ channel.)

6. K_L⁰ → e⁺ + e⁻  
 • Although the decay K_L⁰ → e⁺e⁻ is not strictly “forbidden” by conservation laws, it is extremely suppressed. In the Standard Model such flavor‐changing neutral current processes occur only via loops (the “GIM mechanism”) and, in addition, there are important CP–selection rules at work. (The K_L⁰ is nearly a CP‐odd state, while a lepton–antilepton pair in an S–wave is CP–even.) Hence the decay is very rare.

7. K⁻ → π⁰ + e⁻  
 • In a normal weak charged–current process the electron is always produced together with its corresponding neutrino—to conserve lepton family number (and, in a more detailed sense, to take care of the proper V–A structure of the weak interaction). A decay producing a π⁰ and an e⁻ without the accompanying neutrino would violate lepton number conservation (and would not arise in the standard W–boson–mediated vertex). Thus the process is forbidden.

8. π⁰ → γ + γ + γ  
 • The π⁰ has positive charge–conjugation parity (C = +1). In electromagnetic interactions the photon has C = –1, and the product of three photons has overall C = (–1)³ = –1. Thus, if C were an exact symmetry it would be forbidden for the π⁰ to decay into three photons. (In fact, the dominant decay is π⁰ → γγ.)

9. K_L⁰ → π⁺ + π⁻  
 • The K_L⁰ is, to a very good approximation, a CP–odd state, whereas the two–pion state is CP–even. In a world with exact CP symmetry such a decay would be forbidden. In the kaon system, the small amount of CP violation permits this decay, but its rate is very suppressed.

10. K⁺ → π⁺ + π⁺ + π⁰  
 • While three–pion decays of the K⁺ are allowed by all the basic conservation laws, the observed amplitudes in K decays exhibit a strong “ΔI = 1/2 rule” (an empirical enhancement of transitions that change isospin by 1/2 relative to those that do not). In many decay modes the “ΔI = 3/2” pieces are suppressed, and in this particular final state the dominant isospin–amplitude is relatively small. (There can also be some phase–space suppression at work.) Hence the branching ratio for this channel is relatively low.

To summarize, the reasons why a given decay is “forbidden” or “suppressed” may be many‐fold: conservation of strangeness (or other quantum numbers like baryon number), kinematics (phase space), helicity suppression (due to the V–A structure of weak interactions), CP or C invariance, and the “ΔI = 1/2 rule” in kaon decays, among others.

The final answers are:

\[
\boxed{
\begin{array}{rcl}
(1) &:& \text{Forbidden by strangeness conservation in strong interactions (only weakly allowed).} \\[1mm]
(2) &:& \text{Kinematically forbidden (the K$^+$ mass is too small to produce 6 pions).} \\[1mm]
(3) &:& \text{Allowed only via the weak charged–current (with ΔS = 1), so its rate is weak–suppressed.} \\[1mm]
(4) &:& \text{Forbidden because baryon number is not conserved (a baryon cannot decay into only mesons).} \\[1mm]
(5) &:& \text{Helicity (chiral) suppression makes } \pi^+\to e^+\nu_e \text{ much rarer than } \pi^+\to\mu^+\nu_\mu\,. \\[1mm]
(6) &:& \text{Highly suppressed because it proceeds via flavor–changing neutral currents and is CP–disfavored.} \\[1mm]
(7) &:& \text{Forbidden because the weak charged–current must produce an }e\text{ together with a neutrino (lepton number conservation).} \\[1mm]
(8) &:& \text{Forbidden by C–conservation; } \pi^0(C=+1) \text{ cannot decay into three photons (overall C = -1).} \\[1mm]
(9) &:& \text{CP violation is required (since K$_L^0$ is nearly CP–odd while } \pi\pi \text{ is CP–even), hence the decay is strongly suppressed.} \\[1mm]
(10) &:& \text{Although allowed, the decay amplitude is suppressed (partly by the ΔI = 1/2 rule) making the process relatively rare.}
\end{array}
}
\]

(6) &:& \text{Highly suppressed because it proceeds via flavor–changing neutral currents and is CP–disfavored.} \\[1mm]
(7) &:& \text{Forbidden because the weak charged–current must produce an }e\text{ together with a neutrino (lepton number conservation).} \\[1mm]
(8) &:& \text{Forbidden by C–conservation; } \pi^0(C=+1) \text{ cannot decay into three photons (overall C = -1).} \\[1mm]
(9) &:& \text{CP violation is required (since K$_L^0$ is nearly CP–odd while } \pi\pi \text{ is CP–even), hence the decay is strongly suppressed.} \\[1mm]
(10) &:& \text{Although allowed, the decay amplitude is suppressed (partly by the ΔI = 1/2 rule) making the process relatively rare.}
\end{array}

solution:
We begin by noting that the pions (or π‐mesons) are the lightest mesons and play a central role in the theory of the strong interaction. They occur in three charge states:

 • π⁺ (positive charge),  
 • π⁰ (neutral),  
 • π⁻ (negative charge).

These three states form an isospin triplet with total isospin I = 1 and third component I₃ = +1, 0, –1, respectively.

Below, we discuss their properties and the experimental methods used to determine their spin, parity, and isospin.

────────────────────────────
1. Properties of the Pions

a) Charge and Mass:  
 – The charged pions (π⁺ and π⁻) have nearly equal masses of approximately 139.6 MeV/c², while the neutral pion (π⁰) has a mass slightly lower at around 135 MeV/c².  
 – They differ in electromagnetic properties: π⁺ and π⁻ carry opposite electric charges, whereas π⁰ is uncharged.

b) Spin and Parity:  
 – The pion is a pseudoscalar particle, meaning it has intrinsic spin J = 0 and negative parity (often denoted by 0⁻).  
 – This assignment is consistent with the notion that pions are quark–antiquark bound states (specifically, often considered as having odd intrinsic parity due to the orbital angular momentum between the constituents).

c) Isospin:  
 – Pions form an isospin triplet (I = 1). The different charge states are viewed as different projections (I₃ = +1, 0, –1) of the isospin vector.  
 – This isospin structure is essential in the description of strong interactions and explains, among other things, the similar masses and related interaction patterns of these mesons.

────────────────────────────
2. Determination of Spin

a) Pion Decays and Angular Distributions:  
 – One of the classic methods to determine the spin of a particle is through its decay product angular distributions.  
 – For example, the charged pion undergoes the decay π⁺ → μ⁺ + ν₍μ₎. In this two-body decay, detailed measurements of the energy and angular distribution of the muon (and its polarization) reveal that the pion had no intrinsic spin, since a nonzero spin would imply nontrivial angular correlations among the decay products.  
 – Similarly, the π⁰ decays predominantly into two photons (π⁰ → γ + γ). The angular correlations of the photon polarizations are consistent with the conservation laws only if the decaying state has J = 0.

b) Experimental Techniques:  
 – Early experiments in bubble chambers and cloud chambers recorded the decay tracks and product momenta.  
 – The isotropy of the decay distributions in the pion rest frame provided strong evidence against any spin alignment, thereby confirming the spin-zero assignment.

────────────────────────────
3. Determination of Parity

a) Analysis via Decay Modes:  
 – The decay π⁰ → γγ is especially important for parity determination.  
 – Since the parity of the two-photon state depends on both the intrinsic parity of the photon and their relative orbital angular momentum, one finds that conservation of parity in the electromagnetic decay is only possible if the decaying pion has negative parity.  
 – Detailed analyses of the angular distributions of the photon pair, and the interference between different multipole amplitudes, have been performed to rule out a positive parity assignment.

b) Pion Capture Experiments:  
 – In experiments involving the capture of π⁻ by protons (or nuclei), the angular distributions of emitted photons are measured.  
 – The interference patterns observed in the capture processes are consistent with the pion’s negative intrinsic parity.

c) Overall Conclusion:  
 – Experimental confirmations from decay angular correlations, as well as studies of pion absorption and capture, have firmly established that the pions are pseudoscalar mesons (J^P = 0⁻).

────────────────────────────
4. Determination of Isospin

a) Classification by Charge States:  
 – The very existence of three pion charge states that are nearly degenerate in mass suggested an underlying symmetry – the isospin symmetry.  
 – The grouping into a triplet (I = 1) with different I₃ projections hinges on the nearly identical strong interaction properties of these states.

b) Pion–Nucleon Scattering:  
 – A wealth of data comes from experiments where pions are scattered off nucleons (πN scattering).  
 – In these experiments, differential cross sections are measured for reactions like π⁺ p, π⁻ p, and π⁰ p scattering.  
 – Partial-wave analysis of the scattering amplitudes shows contributions from isospin states (I = 1/2 and I = 3/2). Notably, the appearance of the Δ(1232) resonance (with I = 3/2) in the reaction channels reinforces the isospin assignments and allows one to disentangle the various isospin contributions.

c) Charge Exchange Reactions and Bubble Chamber Data:  
 – Reactions such as π⁻ p → π⁰ n provide clear signatures of isospin symmetry in strong interactions.  
 – Detailed analysis of bubble chamber photographs has served to validate the isospin conservation in pion interactions, confirming that the three pions form an isovector (I = 1).

────────────────────────────
5. Summary

The experimental determination of these key quantum numbers has utilized a combination of decay studies, scattering experiments, and detailed angular correlation analyses:

 • The spin of the pion was inferred to be zero (J = 0) from the isotropic angular distributions in its decays (both in π → μν and π⁰ → γγ decays).  
 • The parity, determined through the analysis of electromagnetic decays and capture processes, is found to be negative (0⁻), consistent with the theoretical expectation for a pseudoscalar meson.  
 • The isospin structure (I = 1) of the pions is established by the existence of three nearly degenerate charge states and is further supported by pion–nucleon scattering experiments and the observation of resonances corresponding to definite isospin states.

────────────────────────────
Final Answer

Thus, the pions (π⁺, π⁰, π⁻) are pseudoscalar mesons characterized by zero intrinsic spin (J = 0) and negative parity (0⁻) and form an isospin triplet (I = 1), with the experimental evidence provided by isotropic decay distributions, detailed analyses of electromagnetic decay modes, capture experiments, and pion–nucleon scattering data.

\[
\boxed{\text{Pions are 0⁻ pseudoscalar mesons forming an isospin triplet (I = 1). Their spin (J = 0) is confirmed by isotropic decay distributions in π → μν and π⁰ → γγ decays; their negative parity is shown by analyzing the two-photon decay angular correlations and pion capture experiments; their isospin assignment (I = 1) is established via consistent patterns in pion–nucleon scattering and charge-exchange reactions.}}
\]

We start with the annihilation of a (nearly) at‐rest antiproton with a proton. In such a collision the available energy is essentially just the two rest energies:
  E_total = mₚc² + mₚ̄c² ≃ 938 MeV + 938 MeV = 1876 MeV.

In the first reaction the final state consists of four pions (two π⁻ and two π⁺). The rest energy of each pion is
  m_πc² = 140 MeV.
Thus the total rest energy for the four pions is
  4 × 140 MeV = 560 MeV.
The remaining energy shows up as kinetic energy.

Step by step we solve the parts:

──────────────────────────── 
Step (a): Average kinetic energy per pion

The total kinetic energy available is
  E_kin,tot = 1876 MeV − 560 MeV = 1316 MeV.
If this energy is shared equally among 4 pions then the average kinetic energy per pion is
  ⟨T⟩ = 1316 MeV / 4 = 329 MeV.

──────────────────────────── 
Step (b): Magnitude of the pion’s momentum

For one pion the total energy (rest plus kinetic) is
  E = T + m_πc² = 329 MeV + 140 MeV = 469 MeV.
In relativistic mechanics the relation between total energy, momentum, and rest energy is
  E² = (pc)² + (m_πc²)².
Thus, solving for the momentum we have
  p = (1/c) √[E² − (m_πc²)²].
Plug in the numbers:
  p = √(469² – 140²) MeV/c.
Calculating the squares:
  469² = 219961  and  140² = 19600,
so
  p = √(219961 − 19600) MeV/c = √200361 MeV/c ≃ 447.6 MeV/c.
It is fine to round this to about 448 MeV/c.

──────────────────────────── 
Step (c): Magnitude of the velocity

For a relativistic particle the speed (in units of c) can be written as
  β = v/c = p/E,
with p and E in the same units (here MeV/c and MeV, respectively). Thus,
  β ≃ 447.6 MeV/c / 469 MeV ≃ 0.954.
So the velocity is approximately 0.954 times the speed of light.

──────────────────────────── 
Step (d): Wavelength of each photon if the annihilation produces 2 photons

Now suppose instead that the annihilation yields two photons. The total energy available is the same, 1876 MeV, and it is shared equally between the two photons. Thus, each photon has energy
  E_γ = 1876 MeV / 2 = 938 MeV.
The energy of a photon is related to its wavelength by
  E_γ = (hc)/λ.
Thus, the wavelength is
  λ = (hc)/E_γ.

It is easiest to use the handy conversion factor available when expressing hc in proper units. (Recall that h-bar c ≃ 197 MeV·fm and h c = 2π (h-bar c) ≃ 1240 MeV·fm.) Since 1 fm = 10^(–13) cm, we have
  hc = 1240 MeV·fm = 1240 MeV × 10^(–13) cm = 1.24 × 10^(–10) MeV·cm.
Thus,
  λ = (1.24 × 10^(–10) MeV·cm) / (938 MeV) ≃ 1.32 × 10^(–13) cm.

──────────────────────────── 
Final Answers

(a) The average kinetic energy per pion is about 329 MeV.

(b) The momentum of a pion with that energy is approximately 448 MeV/c.

(c) The speed corresponding to that momentum is about 0.95c (more precisely 0.954c).

(d) For a two‐photon annihilation, each gamma ray would have a wavelength of approximately 1.32 × 10^(–13) cm.

Thus, we box the final answers:

\[ \boxed{
\begin{aligned}
(a)\quad & 329\,{\rm MeV},\\[1mm]
(b)\quad & 4.48\times10^2\,{\rm MeV}/c,\\[1mm]
(c)\quad & 0.95\,c,\\[1mm]
(d)\quad & 1.32\times10^{-13}\,{\rm cm}.
\end{aligned}
} \]

We start with the two reactions that provide information about mass‐differences.

Step 1. Consider the reaction

  ³He(n, p) → ³H

When written in terms of (atomic) masses we have
  m(n) + m(³He_atom) = m(¹H_atom) + m(³H_atom) + Q
where Q is the energy released, given as 0.770 MeV. Rearranging this gives

  m(n) – m(¹H_atom) = [m(³H_atom) – m(³He_atom)] + Q  (1)

Step 2. Next, we use the fact that tritium (³H) is radioactive and decays via

  ³H → ³He + e⁻ + ν̄

The maximum kinetic energy of the electrons emitted is essentially the Q–value for this beta decay. By atomic mass differences (including the fact that the atomic masses automatically include the appropriate number of electrons) the energy available is

  m(³H_atom) – m(³He_atom) ≈ 0.018 MeV  (2)

Step 3. Substituting (2) into (1) we obtain

  m(n) – m(¹H_atom) = 0.018 MeV + 0.770 MeV = 0.788 MeV

Step 4. To convert this energy difference into atomic mass units (amu), use the conversion factor:
  1 amu ≡ 931 MeV.
Thus,
  m(n) – m(¹H_atom) = 0.788 MeV / 931 MeV/amu ≈ 8.47×10⁻⁴ amu

Rounding to two significant figures gives approximately 8.5×10⁻⁴ amu.

Final answer:

    \(\boxed{8.5\times10^{-4}\,\text{amu}}\)

solution:
We will show that if only isospin is used (with all “phase–space” differences ignored) then only those final‐states which can “make” an I=1 state (with the correct third component) can be produced. In the problem the excited Σ^0 (with mass 1915 MeV/c²) is known to have total isospin
  I = 1  and  I₃ = 0.

Below we “analyze” each decay mode.

──────────────────────────────
1. Decay into K⁻p and K̄⁰n

The kaons come in a doublet with I=1/2. (One may choose conventions so that the members are
  K⁻: I = 1/2, I₃ = –1/2  and  K̄⁰: I= 1/2, I₃ = +1/2.)
Likewise, the nucleons form an isospin doublet
  p: I = 1/2, I₃ = +1/2  and  n: I = 1/2, I₃ = –1/2.
Thus the two‐body final state KN may be obtained by adding two I=1/2’s:
  1/2 ⊗ 1/2 = 0 ⊕ 1.
Since the strong decay operator (which – in the SU(2) limit – is an isoscalar) cannot change the total isospin, the final state must have the same isospin as the initial state, namely I = 1. (Any I = 0 piece is “forbidden” by isospin conservation.)

Write the I=1, I₃=0 state in the KN system using Clebsch–Gordan coefficients. One finds (choosing a standard phase convention)
  |1,0⟩_(KN) = (1/√2)|K⁻ p⟩ + (1/√2)|K̄⁰ n⟩.
Thus the amplitude for producing K⁻p is proportional to 1/√2 and that for producing K̄⁰n is also proportional to 1/√2. (Other factors being the same, the rate is proportional to the square of the amplitude.) Therefore one immediately finds
  (Γ_{K̄⁰n}/Γ_{K⁻p}) = (1/2)/(1/2) = 1.

──────────────────────────────
2. Decay into π⁻p

Now consider the channel π⁻p. (The pion has I = 1.) In our usual isospin assignment we have:
  π⁻: I = 1, I₃ = –1  and  p: I = 1/2, I₃ = +1/2.
Thus the two‐particle π⁻p system has third–component
  I₃(total) = (–1) + (+1/2) = –1/2.
Also, when one adds I = 1 plus I = 1/2 the possible total isospins are
  1 ⊗ 1/2 = 1/2 ⊕ 3/2.
Note that neither of these possibilities is I = 1. (In other words, there is no way to “make” an overall isospin I = 1 state out of a pion and a nucleon with those I values.) Since the decay of a particle of isospin I = 1 by an isoscalar operator can only yield a final state with I = 1 (and with the correct I₃, namely 0), the π⁻p channel is forbidden by isospin conservation. (One may get zero when one projects the πN states onto an I = 1 state.) Thus
  (Γ_{π⁻p}/Γ_{K⁻p}) = 0.

──────────────────────────────
3. Decay into π⁺π⁻

Finally, let us consider the channel in which the final state consists of two pions. (Notice that the pion–pion system has no baryon. In a true baryon decay the baryon number must be conserved. Hence one “expects” that two–meson channels of a baryon involve extra particles or proceed by “different” mechanisms. In the context of an isospin–analysis problem like this one one is intended to assume that all the modes under discussion have comparable phase space and similar “reduced” amplitudes; the point is then to see which ones are allowed or forbidden solely on isospin grounds.)

Two pions (each with I = 1) may be combined:
  1 ⊗ 1 = 0 ⊕ 1 ⊕ 2.
Thus, in principle, the ππ system can have an I = 1 component. (Since the Σ⁰ has I = 1, only the I = 1 piece can be fed by an isospin‐conserving decay.) One may write the I = 1, I₃ = 0 state (with the usual phase conventions) as
  |1,0⟩_(ππ) = (1/√2)[|π⁺π⁻⟩ – |π⁻π⁺⟩].
Now, note that the state |π⁺π⁻⟩ itself (when the two pions are “labeled” by their charges) does not have a definite symmetry under exchange. However, if the decay operator (again being an isoscalar) produces only an I = 1 ππ system then the amplitude for producing the π⁺π⁻ channel is proportional to the appropriate Clebsch–Gordan coefficient for its overlap with the I = 1, I₃ = 0 state. In many such problems one assumes that the “reduced” amplitudes (i.e. the dynamical pieces apart from the known CG factors) for the various channels are of the same magnitude. In our case the amplitude for producing the ππ final state in the I = 1 channel is proportional to 1/√2, exactly as in the KN case.

Thus, had there been a “pure” two–body decay into ππ with baryon‐number conservation ensured by a corresponding “recoil” baryon (or some equivalent mechanism), one would have obtained an amplitude of the same size as for the KN channels. (In our “ratio‐by‐isospin” exercise we are meant to assume that aside from the CG coefficients the dynamics is the same.) In that case
  (Γ_{π⁺π⁻}/Γ_{K⁻p}) = ( (1/√2)² )/( (1/√2)² ) = 1.
Of course, if one were to “complete” the analysis one might ask that in a true decay of a baryon the two–meson final state must be accompanied by a baryon so that the channels here refer to two–body decays into (meson + baryon). (For example, many excited baryons decay into a lower–mass baryon plus a “meson cloud” that sometimes is dominated by two pions.) But with the information given we are to “ignore” such extra details and only use the isospin algebra.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer

Thus, under the assumptions that only isospin‐conserving (i.e. strong) decays occur and that aside from CG factors the reduced amplitudes are the same, we have shown that

  (1) Γ(Σ⁰(1915) → K̄⁰ n) = Γ(Σ⁰(1915) → K⁻ p)  ⇒ Γ_{K̄⁰ n}/Γ_{K⁻ p} = 1,
  (2) Γ(Σ⁰(1915) → π⁻ p) = 0            ⇒ Γ_{π⁻ p}/Γ_{K⁻ p} = 0,
  (3) Γ(Σ⁰(1915) → π⁺ π⁻) has the same reduced CG factor as the KN modes  ⇒ Γ_{π⁺ π⁻}/Γ_{K⁻ p} = 1.

Thus, our final results are

  (Γ_{K̄⁰ n}/Γ_{K⁻ p}, Γ_{π⁻ p}/Γ_{K⁻ p}, Γ_{π⁺ π⁻}/Γ_{K⁻ p})
     = (1, 0, 1).

We now give the final answer in the requested boxed LaTeX form:

\[
\boxed{\frac{\Gamma_{K^{0}p}}{\Gamma_{K^-p}} = 1,\quad \frac{\Gamma_{\pi^-p}}{\Gamma_{K^-p}} = 0,\quad \frac{\Gamma_{\pi^+\pi^-}}{\Gamma_{K^-p}} = 1.}
\]

(Here we have used the common notation K⁰p ≡ K̄⁰n.)

Step 1. Determine the Lorentz factor (γ):

The proper lifetime of the kaon is given as
  τ₀ = 1.2 × 10⁻⁸ s.
A kaon’s rest mass is approximately
  m₀ ≈ 494 MeV/c².
Given that the energy of the kaon beam is
  E = 2 GeV = 2000 MeV,
the Lorentz factor is
  γ = E/m₀ = 2000/494 ≈ 4.05.

Step 2. Write the survival probability in the lab frame:

When moving, the decay law in the lab frame is
  N = N₀ exp(–t/τ_lab),
where the dilated lifetime in the lab frame is
  τ_lab = γτ₀.

Alternatively, for a particle traveling a distance L, the survival probability is
  N/N₀ = exp[–L/(γcτ₀)],
since t = L/v and for highly relativistic particles v ≈ c.

We want the flux (or number) to drop to 10% of its initial value:
  exp[–L/(γcτ₀)] = 0.1.

Step 3. Solve for L:

Take the natural logarithm of both sides:
  –L/(γcτ₀) = ln(0.1) = –ln(10).
Thus,
  L = γ c τ₀ ln(10).

Step 4. Plug in the numbers:

Using
  γ ≈ 4.05,
  c = 3 × 10⁸ m/s,
  τ₀ = 1.2 × 10⁻⁸ s,
  ln(10) ≈ 2.3026,
we find
  L = 4.05 × (3 × 10⁸ m/s) × (1.2 × 10⁻⁸ s) × 2.3026.

First, compute γτ₀:
  4.05 × 1.2 × 10⁻⁸ s = 4.86 × 10⁻⁸ s.

Now, multiply by c:
  4.86 × 10⁻⁸ s × 3 × 10⁸ m/s = 14.58 m.

Finally, multiply by ln(10):
  L ≈ 14.58 m × 2.3026 ≈ 33.6 m.

Step 5. Conclusion:

Thus, the distance required for the flux to be reduced to 10% of its initial value is approximately 33 m.

Final Answer:
  \[\boxed{33\,\text{m}}\]

solution:
Step 1: Understanding Charge Independence

The nuclear force is said to be charge independent because—once electromagnetic effects are removed—the force between any two nucleons (neutron–neutron, proton–proton, or neutron–proton) is nearly the same. However, “charge independence” does not imply that every possible combination of nucleons will have the same binding properties.

Step 2: The Bound n–p (Deuteron) State

The deuteron, a bound state of a neutron and a proton, exists in a state with total spin S = 1 (triplet state) and isospin T = 0. The force in this channel is strongly attractive partly due to the tensor component of the nuclear force, which plays a crucial role in binding the deuteron.

Step 3: Why Two Neutrons Do Not Bind

For two neutrons, there is an additional restriction because they are identical fermions. The overall wavefunction must be antisymmetric under particle exchange, which forces the spatial and spin parts of the wavefunction to compensate each other. In the case of two neutrons, the allowed low-energy state is the spin singlet state (S = 0) with isospin T = 1. Unfortunately, the nuclear force in this spin–singlet/isospin–triplet channel is less attractive than in the spin–triplet/isospin–singlet channel. Hence, the attraction is not strong enough to produce a bound state of two neutrons.

Step 4: What This Reveals about the Nucleon–Nucleon Force

The fact that the n–p system is bound while the nn system is not tells us that the nucleon–nucleon force is not just charge independent, but also strongly depends on the spin and isospin configurations. In other words, the effective potential between nucleons varies with the quantum numbers of the system. In summary, the nucleon–nucleon force has significant spin dependence and isospin dependence, meaning that even though the underlying interaction is symmetric with respect to interchange of protons and neutrons, the details of the binding depend on the allowed quantum states.

Final Answer:

\[
\boxed{
\text{The deuteron (np) is bound because it is in the strongly attractive spin-triplet (S=1), isospin-singlet (T=0) channel, whereas two neutrons, forced by their identical nature into the spin-singlet (S=0), isospin-triplet (T=1) state, experience a weaker attraction that fails to bind them. This indicates that the nucleon–nucleon force is highly spin– and isospin–dependent, despite its overall charge independence.}
}
\]

solution:
We wish to study the effect of “smearing out” the nuclear charge over a sphere of radius R rather than having a point‐charge. For an atom with nuclear charge +Ze (and one electron) the potential energy is modified only for r inside the nucleus. (Outside the nucleus the electric field is the same as that of a point charge by Gauss’s law.) We now describe a worked solution in three parts:

──────────────────────────────
Step (a): Potential for a Finite‐Sized Nucleus

Assume that the (protons) are uniformly distributed in a sphere of radius R. Then the charge density is

  ρ = (Ze)/( (4π/3) R^3 ).

Outside the nucleus (r ≥ R) one recovers the usual Coulomb potential
  V(r) = – Ze^2/r  (for r ≥ R).

Inside the sphere (r < R) one may compute the electric field (using Gauss’s law) and then integrate to get the potential. (One must choose the integration constant so that the potential is continuous at r = R.) A standard result shows that

  V(r) = – (Ze^2)/(2R) [3 – (r^2/R^2)]  (for r < R).

Thus one acceptable answer is

  V(r) = { – (Ze^2)/(r),  r ≥ R,
      – (Ze^2)/(2R)[3 – (r^2/R^2)],  r < R. }

──────────────────────────────
Step (b): Level Shift for the 1s State by Perturbation Theory

Because the “finite‐size” effect differs from the point–charge potential only for r < R and since R is assumed to be much smaller than the Bohr radius a₀, we may treat the difference

  δV(r) = V_uniform(r) – V_point(r)
      = – (Ze^2)/(2R)[3 – (r^2/R^2)] + Ze^2/r  (for r < R)
         = Ze^2 { 1/r – [3 – (r^2/R^2)]/(2R) }  (for r < R)
      and δV(r)=0 for r ≥ R,
 
as a small “perturbation.” (For r ≥ R there is no difference.)
 
Since the unperturbed 1s wavefunction (in the hydrogenic Coulomb field) is

  ψ₁ₛ(r) = (1/√π) (Z/a₀)^(3/2) exp(–Zr/a₀),
 
and since R ≪ a₀ the exponential is essentially unity for r ≤ R. Thus, we may approximate

  |ψ₁ₛ(r)|² ≃ |ψ₁ₛ(0)|² = (Z³)/(πa₀³)  for r ≤ R.
 
The first–order energy shift is then

  ΔE = ∫₀ᴿ |ψ₁ₛ(r)|² δV(r) d³r
     ≃ |ψ₁ₛ(0)|² · 4π ∫₀ᴿ δV(r) r² dr.

We now compute the radial integral I:
 
  I = ∫₀ᴿ δV(r) r² dr = Ze^2 ∫₀ᴿ { 1/r – [3 – (r^2/R^2)]/(2R) } r² dr.
 
Break the integral into two parts:
 
  I = Ze^2 { ∫₀ᴿ r² (1/r) dr – (1/(2R)) ∫₀ᴿ [3 – (r²/R²)] r² dr }.
 
Now, compute the necessary integrals:
 
  • ∫₀ᴿ r dr = R²/2.
  • ∫₀ᴿ r² dr = R³/3.
  • ∫₀ᴿ r⁴ dr = R⁵/5.
 
The second integral becomes:
 
  ∫₀ᴿ [3 – (r²/R²)] r² dr = 3∫₀ᴿ r² dr – (1/R²)∫₀ᴿ r⁴ dr
                = 3(R³/3) – (R⁵/(5R²)) = R³ – R³/5 = (4/5) R³.
 
Thus,
 
  I = Ze² { (R²/2) – (1/(2R))·[(4/5) R³] }
     = Ze² [ R²/2 – (2R/5) ]
     = Ze² R² (1/2 – 2/5)
     = Ze² R² ( (5 – 4)/10 )
     = (Ze² R²)/10.
 
Then the energy shift is
 
  ΔE ≃ |ψ₁ₛ(0)|² · 4π · (Ze² R²/10)
     = (Z³/(π a₀³)) 4π (Ze²R²/10)
     = (4 Z⁴ e²/(10a₀³)) R²
     = (2 Z⁴ e²/(5 a₀³)) R².
 
This is our answer for (b):
 
  ΔE₁ₛ ≃ (2Z⁴e²/(5a₀³)) R².

It is sometimes rewritten in terms of the Rydberg energy (recalling that for the hydrogen atom Ry = e²/(2a₀)) as
 
  ΔE₁ₛ = (4 Z⁴ Ry/(5)) (R²/a₀²).

──────────────────────────────
Step (c): Numerical Estimate for ¹¹Pb (Lead-208)

We are to use 
  R = r₀ A^(1/3), with r₀ = 1.2 fm = 1.2×10^(–13) cm,
and
  A = 208 → A^(1/3) ≃ 208^(1/3) ≃ 5.93.
 
Thus,
  R ≃ 1.2×10^(–13) cm × 5.93 ≃ 7.12×10^(–13) cm.
 
Also, for lead Z = 82 and the Bohr radius is
 
  a₀ = 0.529×10^(–8) cm.
 
Our formula above written in terms of Ry is
 
  ΔE₁ₛ = (4 Z⁴ Ry/(5)) (R²/a₀²).
 
Let’s now compute the dimensionless ratio:
 
  (R/a₀)² = (7.12×10^(–13) cm / 0.529×10^(–8) cm)² 
        ≃ (1.346×10^(–4))² 
        ≃ 1.81×10^(–8).
 
Next, compute Z⁴. Since Z = 82,
  82² = 6724  and  82⁴ = (82²)² ≃ (6724)² ≃ 4.52×10⁷.
 
Thus, the coefficient is
 
  (4 Z⁴/(5)) · (R²/a₀²) ≃ (4×4.52×10⁷/5)×1.81×10^(–8).
 
First, 4×4.52×10⁷ = 1.808×10⁸ and then dividing by 5 gives
 
  1.808×10⁸/5 ≃ 3.616×10⁷.
 
Multiplying by 1.81×10^(–8) gives
 
  3.616×10⁷ × 1.81×10^(–8) ≃ 0.655.
 
Thus, in energy,
 
  ΔE₁ₛ ≃ 0.655 × Ry.
 
Since Ry ≃ 13.6 eV, we obtain
 
  ΔE₁ₛ ≃ 0.655 × 13.6 eV ≃ 8.9 eV.
 
Finally, we convert this energy into wavenumbers. (The conversion is: 1 eV ≃ 8065.5 cm^(–1).) Thus,
 
  ΔE₁ₛ ≃ 8.9 eV × 8065.5 cm^(–1)/eV ≃ 71800 cm^(–1) (approximately).
 
──────────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) The electron potential is
  for r ≥ R: V(r) = – Ze²/r,

A 100‐MW reactor produces 100 × 10^6 joules per second.

Step 2: Determine the energy released per fission.
A typical fission releases roughly 200 MeV of energy. Converting this to joules:

  Since 1 eV ≈ 1.602 × 10^(-19) J,

We shall show step‐by‐step how to answer both parts.

──────────────────────────────
Step (a): The Principal Energy-Producing Chain in the Sun

1. • The Sun’s primary energy source is the proton–proton (p–p) chain. In its simplest form, four protons eventually fuse to form an α–particle (⁴He) by the following main steps:

  (a) First step (the bottleneck):
   p + p → d + e⁺ + νₑ

  Here, two protons fuse. Because one proton must convert into a neutron (a process mediated by the weak interaction), this reaction is very slow; it is the “slow link” in the chain.

  (b) The deuteron (d) produced then captures another proton:
   d + p → ³He + γ

  (c) Finally, two ³He nuclei fuse:
   ³He + ³He → ⁴He + 2p

2. • Neutrinos are produced in the first reaction. Their energy spectrum is broad (a three-body decay) with an endpoint of about 0.42 MeV; the mean energy is approximately ~0.3 MeV.

3. • Estimate of the Neutrino Flux:
  The solar constant is given as roughly 1 kW/m² (i.e. 1000 J/s per m²). Every complete “p–p chain” reaction (which turns 4 protons into a ⁴He nucleus) releases about 26–27 MeV of energy (in total, including what is carried away by the neutrinos). Converting 27 MeV into joules:
   27 MeV ≈ 27×10⁶ eV and 1 eV ≈ 1.6×10⁻¹⁹ J,
  so the energy per reaction is ≈ 4.32×10⁻¹² J.

  Since each complete chain produces 2 neutrinos (from the first step), the reaction rate per m² is approximately
   (1000 J/s/m²) / (4.32×10⁻¹² J/reaction) ≈ 2.3×10¹⁴ reactions/m²/s.
  Thus, the p–p neutrino flux is
   ≈ 2 × (2.3×10¹⁴) = 4.6×10¹⁴ ν/m²/s.
  Converting to cm² (1 m² = 10⁴ cm²), we obtain a flux of roughly
   4.6×10¹⁰ ν/cm²/s.
  This value is usually quoted as of order 6×10¹⁰ cm⁻² s⁻¹, allowing for some details in the energy budget and solar model.

──────────────────────────────
Step (b): Minor Reactions Leading to the High-Energy Neutrino Component

1. • In addition to the dominant p–p chain, there is a branch in which ³He fuses with ⁴He. This leads to the production of ⁷Be:

  ³He + ⁴He → ⁷Be + γ

2. • This ⁷Be can then follow two paths. In about 90% of cases, it undergoes electron capture:
   ⁷Be + e⁻ → ⁷Li + νₑ
  to produce monochromatic neutrinos with energies of about 0.86 MeV (there is also a minor line around 0.38 MeV). In the rarer but crucial branch for high-energy neutrinos, ⁷Be captures a proton:
   ⁷Be + p → ⁸B + γ
  and the resulting ⁸B undergoes β⁺ decay:
   ⁸B → ⁸Be* + e⁺ + νₑ
  The ⁸B β-decay produces a continuum of neutrinos with energies extending up to ~15 MeV (with a mean of several MeV, roughly ~7 MeV). 

3. • Detection in the Homestake Chlorine Experiment:
  The experiment uses a large tank filled with C₂Cl₄ (perchloroethylene). The detection reaction is
   ³⁷Cl + νₑ → ³⁷Ar + e⁻,
  which has a threshold of ~0.8 MeV. Thus, while the lower-energy p–p neutrinos are largely “invisible” to this detector, the high-energy neutrinos from ⁸B (and in part, those from ⁷Be) are detectable.
  Argon atoms produced by the neutrino interactions are extracted (by purging with helium) and their decays counted.

4. • Findings to Date:
  Measurements consistently showed that the observed neutrino capture rate (typically expressed in Solar Neutrino Units, where 1 SNU = 10⁻³⁶ captures per target atom per second) is significantly below the predictions from standard solar models. This “solar neutrino problem” eventually led to the discovery that neutrinos change flavor en route from the sun to the earth (i.e. neutrino oscillations), a result that has been confirmed by numerous later experiments.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer

We begin by noting that strong interactions are approximately invariant under SU(2) isospin symmetry. However, certain small effects – such as the electromagnetic interaction and the u–d quark mass difference – break this symmetry. (a) In order to account for these corrections when writing the masses of members of an isospin multiplet (i.e. isobars with the same mass number A but different charge), one can decompose the mass operator M in terms of isospin operators. Since the mass operator is a scalar under rotations in ordinary space but not under isospin, we write it as a sum of “allowed” pieces that transform with different isospin representations: 

 1. An isoscalar term (which is invariant under isospin rotations), and thus independent of isospin,
 2. An isovector term (which transforms like Tz),
 3. And an isotensor (or second‐order) term (which is taken to be quadratic in Tz).

Thus one writes:
  M = a (isoscalar) + b (isovector) + c (isotensor).

Since the only available isospin operator (or rather its third component) is Tz, we have
  M = a + bTz + c Tz².

The physical interpretation is as follows:
 • The constant a represents the average mass of the multiplet (the “center-of-mass” of the masses);
 • The term bTz reflects effects that are linear in Tz. These arise, for example, from the u–d mass difference which gives a shift in the mass proportional to the third component of the isospin;
 • The quadratic term cTz² is largely due to electromagnetic (Coulomb) energy differences. (Since the electromagnetic energy is roughly proportional to the square of the charge – and since charge is related to Tz – one expects a Tz² dependence.)

A more formal derivation makes use of the Wigner–Eckart theorem and the notion that, when one expands the mass operator in symmetry-adapted operators, the only allowed terms have the forms a, bTz, and cTz² (plus a constant that can be absorbed into a term independent of Tz).

(b) In order to test the quadratic formula experimentally one must be able to determine all three coefficients – a, b, and c – from a fit to the masses of the multiplet members. To determine three parameters one needs at least three distinct measurements. In an isospin multiplet of total isospin T, the third component Tz takes the values −T, −T+1, …, T. 

A multiplet with T = 1/2 contains only two values (Tz = ±1/2), which is insufficient to determine a quadratic term. The smallest multiplet that yields three distinct values is T = 1 (producing Tz = −1, 0, +1). Thus, one must have an isospin multiplet with T ≥ 1 in order to test experimentally that the mass formula is quadratic in Tz.

Final Answer:
 (a) By expanding the mass operator in terms of operators that transform as an isoscalar, isovector, and isotensor, we obtain
  M = a + bTz + cTz².
 (b) To test the quadratic dependence (i.e. to determine the three parameters a, b, and c) one needs a multiplet with at least three members, meaning T ≥ 1.

\[
\boxed{\text{(a) } M =a+bT_z+cT_z^2 \quad\text{and}\quad \text{(b) } T\ge1.}
\]
